column4: Further to my query yesterday about my 4K smart tv screen going  I am pleased to say we successfully swapped it for a new one today at the Gloucester Quays store. What I would like to add is we were grateful to Callum who was the person serving us. we were in the store for an hour and forty five minutes trying to locate stock there or another if they didn t have it. I have to say Callum did everything possible  nothing was too much trouble for him to deal with our faulty tv. He was polite and was trying his best to resolve the issue there and then aswell as doing other jobs on the customer service desk. He made what could have been a stressful situation into one that really wasn t. I really hope he gets recognised for his great customer service we can t fault him. Please pass on our thanks
column9: Hey! Aww fabulous it's always good to know our colleagues are going the extra mile for our customers. Can I ask was this at the Customer Services or Electrical department? I will get this passed on. It's good you found a replacement. Kelly.

column9: I understand its popularity, that was the reason I had secured, or so I thought, one by ordering online. column9: If you bought 16 bottles it will only show as 11Ã—25% on your reciept as the 1st 6 bottles is one offer of 25% off and then each bottle after. eg your 7th bottle will be offer 2, your 8th bottle offer 3 so on so on. Hope this helps a bit. Took us ages to work it out when i worked there x

column4: As a regular Sainsburys customer for absolutely years my elderly 86 year old lovely nan who suffers from mixed dementia has np shopping today as she should have had delivery between 12/1pm.. The driver turned up early could not use the keysafe????  We have carers a cleaner a hairdresser friends Wiltshire farm foods who all can... He then left with her shopping no phone call nothing no contact whatsoever I found out from my nan and rang sainsburys online who rang her local store. The manager said his vans are over loaded and age has to wait until tomorrow!!!!????   Absolutely disgusting customer service lack of customer care no apology no courtesy or compensation.. We will no longer use Sainsburys you have just lost a long standing loyal paying customer for over 20 years

column4: I am finding it increasingly difficult to order food on line that is not wrapped in plastic that cannot be recycled. When I order loose fruit and veg I think at least it s not wrapped in plastic.  You then send it in a plastic bag with a label on it  making it difficult to recyle. I have requested you send them in paper bags like the good old days before plastic. Apparently this is not possible  but you are doing your best for the environment. That s OK then :-)
column9: Hi Hazel. We share your concerns about the effects that plastic has on the environment and, for a number of years, have been focused on reducing our packaging. Loose fruit and veg are placed in a bag to ensure it arrives to our customers in pristine condition. I appreciate you contacting us about your concern and I will pass on your comments to the relevant team. Enjoy the rest of your evening Hazel! Dee

I have requested you send them in paper bags like the good old days before plastic. Apparently this is not possible  but you are doing your best for the environment. That s OK then :-)

column4: Hello lovely people of Sainsbury s. You have a food bank collection box in your store in East Grinstead which is fantastic. I m much more likely to remember an extra item if I ve been reminded before I shop  rather than after. Many thanks.

column4: Very disappointed with Sainsbury s  visited my local store  Castlepoint  Bournemouth @ 9.20 on Monday night  wanted to get some fresh meat from the counter  staff were standing around  doing nothing  and then I was told  It s closed .  Would have taken a few minutes 2 just get me what I wanted.  Yes I understand that the store closes at 10pm  but in my days of retail  the counters were open until the shop closed  then the closing down/clean up would begin  money was money  and a sale was extra money  never turn away a customer.

I'd be happy to pass on the feedback so that in future colleagues will know to explain to customers why they are closing early. Daryl.

column4: I informed Sainsbury s I had paid 40p for 8 carrier bags ( @ 5p each) for an online shop but I only got 5.  You may have seen my post before it got taken off.  Their reply is below.  It appears you pay 40p even if you only get 1 bag   When agreeing to the carrier bag charge it is 40p for however many bags your shop needs. You donâ€™t actually pay for a set amount of bags  do not choose how many you get and the amount you get is determined by your orders need for bags.    We now offer the option for you to choose whether you would like to have your order delivered with or without carrier bags. If you select not to receive bags you will not be charged the 40p carrier bag charge. You can select this option on the checkout page.  Our aim has always been to reduce the number of carrier bags used by our customers  reflecting the environmental objectives set out in the new legislation. We believe that our 5p reusable bags are the most effective way to do this  as they are made of recycled material and are recyclable plus we will replace them free of charge if they become damaged.  We also donate any profits we make from these reusable bags to good causes.  We do however  still provide single use carrier bags for online orders should a customer request their shopping be bagged. We will no longer have single use bags in our English stores as reusable bags are more environmentally friendly and we also believe that our customers will want something sturdier which they can reuse again and again.  We are therefore charging 5p for a reusable bag  in addition to our 10p bag for life. We will continue to use single use carrier bags for our online deliveries and will charge a flat fee of 40p per delivery.
column9: That's precisely why I want the bags because I use them for other things.  I have no objection to paying 5p a bag however I would strongly object to paying 40p if I only got 1.

column4: Just wanted to let you know how disappointed I am with you today. I ordered a Lego Star Wars advent calendar for click and collect today- my day off  ready to arrive with my sons elf on the shelf in the morning. He is 6 years old and questioning whether Santa is real already ðŸ˜¢ so I am going all out this Christmas to make him believe again. He knew the elf was bringing him the advent calendar. column4: Nice to see that you re putting your delivery charges up as it s getting near to Christmas  at this rate it will be cheaper for me to shop at my local co-op  and on the subject  why don t you offer lower delivery rates when there is a green van already in the area on a time slot.
column9: But why should we pay extra, you make loads of money through your customers, you pay the extra, as you will be getting extra profit, due to more people shopping, and buying extra food etc. Still nothing about lower prices for shared green van deliveries, for example, if I gave you an order, and my neighbour gave you an order at Â£5 delivery each, that ten pounds for driving to the same place, so you've made Â£5 profit out of two orders.

column4: Nice to see that you re putting your delivery charges up as it s getting near to Christmas  at this rate it will be cheaper for me to shop at my local co-op  and on the subject  why don t you offer lower delivery rates when there is a green van already in the area on a time slot.
column9: Hi Miriam, our delivery rates will change depending on time and date, owing to the availability of drivers and areas they need to travel to. column4: A massive thank you to the staff at Sainsburys cafe and supermarket in Dewsbury  especially Dee. My little 2 year old  Tilly  has had a really tough couple of weeks with being poorly. We called into the cafe this morning and Tilly was really upset and grumpy - Dee took the time to speak to her and tell her what a lovely girl she is. After we had sat down  Dee came back over with a toy she had bought for Tilly to help keep her calm and occupied whilst I had a few minutes of peace and quiet. It was really appreciated and other customers were really blown away by this kind act and came to talk to Tilly as well. Thank you so much - I used to actually work in this store and cafe and have come here for years. They really do look after their customers ï¿½ xxx

column4: Dear Sainsburys  At one of your stores today I wanted to buy a baby doll for my 18mth old son  so as to stop him constantly stealing his sister s ones. I was disappointed to see how gender stereotyped these dolls were and the choice so limited. We opted for a doll dressed fully in pink with a pink headband as the other choice was a baby dressed in pink or another one dressed in pink. I looked hopefully through the selection of clothes you could buy separately to dress the dolls  again  a pink sleep suit and a purple dress were my options.   Please understand that it is shops that drive the gender stereotyping of childrens toys  not those buying it.   In the real world there are baby boys as well as baby girls. Lots of babies are dressed in neutral coloured clothes or a whole rainbow of other colours (not just blue or pink). Dads look after babies as much as mums so this is not just a girl thing.  I am trying to bring up my children to understand that gender is not relevant in what they choose to do  but so many things surrounding them point otherwise. Perhaps you could consider my comments when looking for new stock.  Kind Regards  Hannah Ringrow
column9: My sentiments exactly when I read this.....but my language wasn't so polite  ðŸ˜¡

column9: Hi Hannah, very sorry you feel this way. At Sainsburyâ€™s we aim to make our customersâ€™ shopping experience as effortless and efficient as possible. Using the customer feedback we receive we've found that when buying children's products, most customers prefer to shop by gender and then age. In line with other major retailers we therefore specify children's ranges under boy's and girl's, much as we do with men's and women's. We believe this makes it easier to navigate and locate products, both in store and online. We really value our customersâ€™ comments, so we take feedback of this nature seriously. Can you confirm which store you visited and I can pass your feedback on? Thanks, Monica.

column4: Hello - have been trying to find your complaints section but it is full of forms and FAQs which are not relevant. SO have 3 complaints  1) you have erected a barrier in the carpark at your Low Hall site which stops us going into part of the carpark in our camper van - which is our regular vehicle. Please can you have this removed.  2) I went shopping at Low Hall yesterday and your security people were removing a Big Issue seller. I asked them what they were doing and why. They said it was Head Office Policy. I said that wasnt a reason! Very strange to see your xmas tree and all the good-willy messages and to see a homeless person treated like that. I bought a Big Issue from him but he was seen off  3) I wish you would get rid of the voucher system - wastes so much time at the checkout ... and also paper!
column9: I noticed the barrier a few weeks ago, but was only closed for the first time in my experience yesterday. I dont understand what you mean by ""our colleagues were not involved""  are the security people I saw coming out of the store to send him packing not your colleagues?

column4: I m disappointed Sainsbury s is still not reducing the amount of packaging they use on their own brand products  and doesn t even change to recyclable packaging so I end up with piles of plastic for landfill than I do food.  For that reason I do most of my shopping elsewhere.  Is there any plan to change (and I mean properly  no half-measures)?
column9: Hello Leon. Thanks for this! I have forwarded this on to the relevant departments within the store. Many Thanks, Kelly.

column4: I m disappointed Sainsbury s is still not reducing the amount of packaging they use on their own brand products  and doesn t even change to recyclable packaging so I end up with piles of plastic for landfill than I do food.  For that reason I do most of my shopping elsewhere.  Is there any plan to change (and I mean properly  no half-measures)?
column9: Hi Kelly! Usually the Clifton Down store on Whiteladies Road in Bristol.  I did use the online feedback form to ask them to look into other options, but nothing is happening.  Examples include the fresh fruit 'n' veg section where my healthy snacks for work would include plastic containers and film lids, only some parts of which are recyclable.  I often used to buy nuts but they're in totally non-recyclable bags.  The deli/hot food section serves things in plastic-paper bags, which being mixed material are also non-recyclable.  I do understand the need to protect the food and stop grease, but there are other ways and all that we are left with a few minutes afterwards is plastic galore.  The amount they sell each week nationwide must mean a ridiculous amount of money is spent on generating waste for landfill. :/

column4: Much as I love Sainsburys for its inclusive policies  I am disappointed with the new coin slots that have been added to my local Sainsburys  trollies (Beckton  London).  The new slots require you to put the coin in a sliding carrier  that is then pushed into the lock release mechanism  thus allowing you to take the trolley.   These are much fiddlier than the previous  push it in the slot  mechanisms  and as a person with arthritic hands  very difficult to operate.  I had to have someone help me with it  as I found pushing the carrier in to be impossible.  Were any Disabled Groups consulted about this new design?  Are there plans to introduce a version that differently abled people (and left handers for that matter) find easier to use?
column9: Hi Liz, For some background on this, this was shown and presented in our disability working group. I think the initial thought was this would be an easier lock to use as you are not having to push the Â£1 coin in, instead you are placing the coin into the lock and pushing the lock into the mechanism. We appreciate the feedback, we will raise this back into the workshop to see how this reflects back. Hayley

column9: Hey Maxine. Really sorry about this! We aim to make our customersâ€™ shopping experience as effortless and efficient as possible. Using customer feedback, we've found that when buying childrensâ€™ products, most customers prefer to shop by gender and then age. In line with other major retailers we therefore specify childrensâ€™ ranges under boysâ€™ and girlsâ€™, much as we do with men and women. We believe this makes it easier to navigate and locate products, both in store and online however you should feel free to purchase whatever items you feel your child would be happiest with. I've logged the details of your experience so that they can be taken into consideration when our ranges are next reviewed, and this'll allow us to continue to improve our products and services. Thanks, Kelly

column4: Hello Sainsburys. My 14 year old daughter was with me in Chester today when we walked past your express store in Watergate Street she noticed that there was cash sticking out of the cash point which had been left behind. We removed it and there was Â£ 50 there and then asked around to see if anyone had seen who used the cash point but no one knew who it was. Holly (my daughter) then had no hesitation in going into your store and handing it in to your staff. I am very proud of her as I am sure you can imagine Â£ 50 would have made her shopping trip in Chester far more enjoyable. Your staff thanked her for being so honest and said that there was a camera at the cash point and if someone did try and claim it then they could check it was theirs. I was hoping you could find out for us from the store if anyone came back to claim it or not. Holly was worried about how the person would feel when they noticed they had lost it. We look forward to hearing from you hopefully. Kind Regards Clair Eccleston  proud Mum of Holly Eccleston
column9: Hi Clair! What a wonderful girl Holly is! I've spoken to the store and the money has been returned to the rightful owner. I'd like to thank Holly for her honesty and send her a gift card for her to spend in store. Can you send us your full postal address in a PM please? Maria

I am very proud of her as I am sure you can imagine Â£ 50 would have made her shopping trip in Chester far more enjoyable. Your staff thanked her for being so honest and said that there was a camera at the cash point and if someone did try and claim it then they could check it was theirs. I was hoping you could find out for us from the store if anyone came back to claim it or not. Holly was worried about how the person would feel when they noticed they had lost it. column4: I love you Tu clothes for kids and my daughter has worn so many over her 4years I can t count. I get completely sick of your labelling of girls and boys clothing - she will be the judge of what she likes!  We have gruffalo pj s from the boys range  it also appears sooty was only available in boys too (one of her favourites). Looking for coats last week I found the girls coats to be very bling and sone in unpractical colours. The boys however we so much better designed with cuffs  hoods  long in the body and with zips and pockets. Needless to say we chose one of those instead!  Now I am amazed to see the Hey Duggee pj set is in the boys section too. What are you thinking?!  They are colourful and completely and utterly gender neutral  all children love hey duggee and that is the point - so why in your opinion do you think girls wouldn t like these?
column9: Hi Liz! Sainsburyâ€™s aim to make our customersâ€™ shopping experience as effortless and efficient as possible.  Using customer feedback, we've found that when buying childrensâ€™ products, most customers prefer to shop by gender and then age.  In line with other major retailers we therefore specify childrensâ€™ ranges under boysâ€™ and girlsâ€™, much as we do with mensâ€™ and womensâ€™.  We believe this makes it easier to navigate and locate products, both in store and online.  We really value our customersâ€™ comments, so we take feedback of this nature seriously. Maria

column4: Dear Sainsbury s   I regularly buy my children s clothes from one of your stores which is local to where I live.  My children are two and four and have a range of interests from playing make believe with toys to outdoor sports and games.  I want them to be warm in the winter and cool in the summer with practical clothes that withstand the general wear and tear of climbing  running  swinging  playing in sand and everything else small children love to do.  They need to be washed after almost every wear due to splashed mud and paint  spilt food and unfortunately the occasional toileting accident.  My children like many colours and enjoy watching a wide variety of TV programmes and films from Pixar to CBeebies.  I am a grown woman in my 30s and I know my children and am able to differentiate between colours and characters that they like without somebody in a marketing department somewhere making arbitrary choices for me.  As a result  I am continually frustrated by the unhelpful way clothes are organised in my local Sainsbury s.  Children s clothes are separated into 3 different age categories as well as gender divides so if I m looking for warm practical trousers that can be worn in the winter months playing outside for both my children  there are 4 different sections I need to look through for me to find something suitable.  If all the trousers were in one place  it would actually make shopping a lot easier.  The gender divide in particular results in awful slogans perpetuating negative stereotypes such as girls are only valued on their appearance and boys are inherently naughty.  Some characters are only available on one gender or age range even though they might have universal appeal.  As an example  clothes with Paw Patrol on them only feature boy characters on the boys clothes and girl characters on the girls clothes.  I have read on another page that you have stated customer preference for arranging clothes as you do but I can honestly say this is not my preference.  Please can you look into organising all children s clothes according to type.  Both my children wear a range of clothes bought from the boys and the girls sections in a variety of shops as well as hand-me-downs from other boys and girls.  Children s body shapes are not that different until they reach puberty and in the interest of bringing up well rounded individuals  I try my hardest not to limit their interests with outdated attitudes.  I have worked in marketing myself and understand the various audience segmentation tools that companies use and how a microscopic focus on ROI leads many companies to treat them as gospel.  In my opinion  however  lazy use of gendered colours  images and slogans just leads to the perpetuation of potentially damaging stereotypes and in this day and age  particularly when it comes to children  I think any company that makes an example of themselves by taking a stand would actually reap far more benefit from a greater proportion of the population.  Kind regards   Lucy Forrest
column9: Thanks for your standard reply.  I look forward to hearing from you when you do your next review.  I will also be contacting my local store and giving them some direct feedback.

column9: Hi Lucy. Thanks for getting in touch. Sainsburyâ€™s aim to make our customersâ€™ shopping experience as effortless and efficient as possible.  Using customer feedback, we've found that when buying childrensâ€™ products, most customers prefer to shop by gender and then age.  In line with other major retailers we therefore specify childrensâ€™ ranges under boysâ€™ and girlsâ€™, much as we do with mensâ€™ and womensâ€™.  We believe this makes it easier to navigate and locate products, both in store and online.  We really value our customersâ€™ comments, so we take feedback of this nature seriously.  I've logged the details of your experience so that they can be taken into consideration when our ranges are next reviewed, and this'll allow us to continue to improve our products and services. Maria

column4: Dear sainsburys I visited your Cheam branch of sainsburys yesterday and my intention was to use my nectar points to buy a bottle of Jack Daniels only to be told at the self checkout that I could not use my points because I was to far away from my home sainsburys.  At this point I had scanned the items I was buying and had scanned a 500 bonus nectar points voucher I had and put this in the voucher compartment. Because of not being able to spend my points I had to ask for assistance to remove the jack Daniels which then caused the checkout to crash meaning I had lost the use of my voucher and had caused a queue. To say I found this a little frustrating at causing a queue  not being able to spend my points loosing out on my bonus points voucher because the checkout crashed.

column4: STOP SELLING HALAL FOOD IN ENGLAND
column9: I happily eat Lamb (hardly intensively farmed), Pork (bred and raised outdoors), Beef (Battery cows, I don't think so), Chicken (unfortunately my choice is limited to my budget, not my conscience), British produce (such as Black Pudding, Scotch Pies etc., when you can find them after being pushed out by foreign produce).......answer your points???? And most Halal meat is certainly NOT stunned first in this country!

column4: STOP SELLING HALAL FOOD IN ENGLAND
column9: I love how naive you are. Any meat from a supermarket is intensively farmed. British produce doesnt mean it isnt very intensively farmed. Especially for pies and things like black pudding ( thats if it is even british meat being used and not that the components arent just put together in the uk to make for example a pie). When you drive along and see cows in fields quite sparsely populated these arent destined for supermarket beef burgers or steaks. Imagine how much meat tesco, morrisons , sainsburys etc sell and for how little they sell it. I bought a chicken for about Â£2.30 a few weeks ago and diced beef for Â£2.59. The only way supermarkets can make money on these products is to intensively farm in a small space. Just raising animals as quickly as they can by constantly feeding them and keeping them awake longer via the use of artificial lighting.

column4: STOP SELLING HALAL FOOD IN ENGLAND
column9: Maybe just dont buy it? Also i would be interested to know what meat you do buy and if its intensively farmed with animals raised in poor and crowded conditions. But aslong as they have a death via stunning thats fine (also most uk slaughtered halal meat is actually stunned)

column4: STOP SELLING HALAL FOOD IN ENGLAND
column9: So an animal can be intensively farmed, kept in a windowless shed, covered in cuts from fighting and being in a dirty environment but aslong as its stunned before slaughter thats fine? Yes one could argue that halal can mean a more painful death but in general meat for supermarkets is one drawn out life of misery. Halal or not.

column4: I am a regular online shopper with sainsburys. Once upon a time you gave an excellent service but lately you dont seem able to deliver my shopping without damaging or missing items. It is true that if i complain i get a voucher but i dont want vouchers i want my shopping to turn up undamaged. This has been going on for many months now and i feel my complaints arnt being heard as the service does not improve. To this end i am going to post here every time i get damaged goods. This week i got 2 packets of squashed tomatoes... so organic  so expensive  so squashed. I also got a packet of butter that had been dropped  mmmm i love road grit in my butter. I do enjoy fruit and regularly order papaya  this time i found one careful thumb print in one. You also missed some pies off my order. You are failing your customers sainsburys  try to hear the feedback.

column4: Sainsbury s...well this evening my thoughts on your reputation for quality products has been severely questioned.  This evening my son and I shopped for household products and food at our local store. On our departure I remembered that we needed logs for our fire.  Our home relies on our log burner a great deal due to the age of the house and other factors.  Tonight my teenage son and I planned a film night.  Pretty unheard of these days as film nights with mum aren t so cool or whatever the word is for that these days. We picked up two bags of logs from your petroleum station on the way out of the store.  Paid Â£6/bag for what I d normally pay half at other high street named store.  But I figured the time saving was worth it  because it meant longer with my son.  So  fast forward to having a lovely evening of film watching and being snug. I asked my lad to open the bag of logs.   They re a bit damp  he says. We tried for over 3 hours to light the driest logs.  No joy...do no toasty room.  Could have saved myself 2 3/4 hours and Â£6 overall on my original Â£12 purchase.  I m not sure that I can find my receipt but I m so beyond disappointed I felt I needed to contact you.  Surely   if you re going to sell these products  you should store them so they should be fit for purpose?  Especially when they are double the cost of many other retailers. These bags of wood are beyond damp (and you cannot tell this when you buy them because of how they are bagged and stored. They just feel as cold as the air around them).  Anyway  we used a blanket to add heat but I am beyond frustrated with you Sainsbury s.

Could have saved myself 2 3/4 hours and Â£6 overall on my original Â£12 purchase.  I m not sure that I can find my receipt but I m so beyond disappointed I felt I needed to contact you. column4: I ve bought some blue LED lights from Sainsburys  my 2 girls were mythering to put the tree up. So this afternoon gave in... tree went up... opened the lights and tested them... working ... GREAT STUFF! So we put the lights on the tree... decorate it which takes us a few hours... turn the lights on and WOW  the tree looked beautiful. 2 happy girls! Hours pass by  were watching T.V whilst we can see the twinkle of lights in the corner of our eyes and all of a sudden there off and it s dark. As you can imagine 2 very unhappy girls. So I check them but lights are simply not working anymore. Tomorrow morning we are going to have to take all the decorations off and then all the lights.... take a 20 minute drive to our nearest store to hopefully exchange (if this the right thing to do as will this happen again???) or get my money back and on the hunt for some more blue LED lights again... gutted and angry is and understatement. ðŸ™
column9: Presumably you checked the  fuse bulb?

Extremely disappointed with my visit to your store in West Green  Crawley yesterday. I took my 85 year old grandfather and my 6 month old daughter in her buggy. I decided we would stop for coffee and cake before shopping  however when we got to the lift to go up to the cafe it was out of order. I then had to walk my grandfather and get the buggy over to customer services to see if there was another way up since the lift wasn t in service  I was advised that the lift had been broken for 2 weeks and they didn t know when it was to be fixed and there was no other way up to the cafe other than the stairs. This was obviously going to prove difficult due to the buggy and my grandfather. In the end I had to ask customer services had to find a member of staff to help me carry my daughter in her buggy up the stairs  wait with her at the top whilst I helped my grandfather up the stairs. Then we had to wait for a member of staff to do the same when we wanted to go down. Luckily there were no accidents when carrying the buggy up and down with my daughter in it!  I understand things break and need fixing but firstly 2 weeks is a long time to have the only lift broken  and secondly we are lucky that my grandfather could use the stairs (albeit took a while for him and knackered him out!). If he was in a wheel chair or not as able  the stairs wouldn t have been an option! By law do you not have to have a lift as essentially you are saying no one in a wheelchair can use your cafe until the lift is fixed?!   Of course we could have not gone to the cafe but my grandfather is diabetic and he needed to eat something to keep his bloods stable.  Not impressed sainsburys with no lift  having to leave my daughter with a stranger  and the general attitude of your customer service staff who really couldn t care less!
column9: Hello. I'm really sorry about this! I hope your grandfather and little girl are okay? I have contacted the store regarding the lift. They are waiting on the repair which they say will be soon as possible. Can you PM us your Nectar number I will log this for you and add points as a way of apology. Thanks, Kelly.

column9: I wasn't planning to eat it tomorrow as we are out all day and my freezer is full at the moment. It's not the point really- the dates are normally a good few days from day of purchase and if I had picked it up in store it would likely be either reduced or I would have picked one up with a few days on it. I might not even have a working freezer at the moment or even have one at all- not everyone does. Then it would be wasted and I hate food waste.  The point is that I should be able to buy meat that doesn't need to be eaten within 27hours of arriving at my house.

column4: I receive vouchers from you  which encourage me to buy from your stores. On the latest  I was required to spend Â£60 to get Â£9 off  which as 15% seemed a good deal. I noted the exclusion of spirits and liqueurs from the offer  and decided to increase my stock of wine at your Waterlooville store. When I got to the checkout  the operator told me that the coupon was not accepted by her machine. I pointed out the lack of excluded items  and she told me that I needed to check the small print on the back of the coupon. I told her I had. She called for a Supervisor  from the group of 4 who were too busy to notice customer needs  so I went to the group and got one to come over. She asked if I had any spirits or liqueurs  and then went away to find another Supervisor. When that Supervisor arrived  she overrode whatever obstacle there was  and the coupon was finally accepted. These coupons are a nice gesture  but if they cause this much hassle to your staff and me  not to mention the customers queueing behind me  then someone needs to take a long hard look at the system.

column4: Dr Mr Sainsbury s   I d like to write a complaint if I may. Myself and two colleagues work shifts covering a 24 hour period for the NHS and on the afternoon of Monday 21st of November we were talking about Black Friday  we all thought it would be a good laugh and a chance to get some bargains to head over to Lincoln s Tritton Road store for approximately 11:45pm ready for the Black Friday deals to be revealed at midnight. In preparation for this little outing we checked your website to see if there was any spoilers as to what was going to be in the deals  to our delight there was a few items - great! Upon searching in a very popular search engine  Sainsbury s Black Friday  your Black Friday page was top of the search engine with a link to your site  once on the site you had a countdown box which was counting down to midnight of Friday 25th November with a message underneath saying  Black Friday deals in store only!  Brilliant  we re all set! Plans were made with meeting places and the designated driver was assigned. Plans were going smoothly despite myself and a colleague finishing late from our shift  spirits were high and it was nice to do something socially. The 20 mile trip was made to our most local 24 hour Sainsbury s talking about what we were looking to buy  especially for our children for Christmas and we arrived at 11:45pm to find the car park very empty. However we just thought people weren t as mad as us! When we arrived at the store there was a number of staff smoking outside the main entrance where the general public were still walking past which I found very disrespectful  personally. As we approached the main entrance one of your staff members said to us   you do know we are shutting at midnight until 6 don t you to get ready for the deals?  We we re all laughing and expecting her to say  just joking!  But she didn t  of course it wasn t her fault she was just a member of staff. However  what disappointed us the most was how misleading your website was  with the countdown ending at midnight we fully expected to be allowed around the store which was 24 hours with no signs saying they would be closing early. Due to the nature of our job we then missed the actual sale at 6am this morning.   And I forgot to get some bread.   A response would be gratefully received.
column9: Hi Charlotte, I can definitely understand your annoyance, sorry about this. More info on our Black Friday offers can be found here: http://help.sainsburys.co.uk/help/offers-promotions/4161-black-friday-16 Apologies again for the hassle you and your friends had. Susanna

column4: Just wanted to let you know that just because you have self service checkouts does not mean you should put less staff on. I was in your Edinburgh south bridge branch this evening and there was just two poor girls working to get through a long queue of people resulting in no one to help me because the machine wasn t weighing my item. The nice bouncer did try to help  but as he is not technically a cashier he couldn t do much. I ended up leaving all my groceries on the check out and going to tesco instead. I will be boycotting sainsburys from now on if you think it is acceptable to give staff less hours and therefore less customer attention. Appalling behaviour especially when a lot of our staff will be already be struggling to pay bills before you doing this. Not that anyone at your HO would understand what it s like to struggle to pay bills. Anyone who reads this  boycott sainsburys and shop somewhere where they care about staff and customer welfare!

column4: I don t normally vent..but I m going to today...I applied for a job at Sainsbury s and got an interview  which went really well  so so chuffed with myself. But i hadn t heard anything after a few days so i decided to ring their head office in manchester to find out whats going on. The lady on the the phone was very nice and apologised for me not getting any emails... so she had a look for me and said  Congratulations you have got the job  Welcome to Sainsbury s  and apologised again for me not being informed. But then she notice the induction day was today (the day I m ringing). she said don t worry i will ring the store and arrange another induction day for you and ring you back.....I was SO HAPPY that i got the job just before christmas. Then they lady rang back  and Crushed My World  said Im sorry you did pass the interview  but there was someone with slightly more experience than me and if she does not except the job then its mine  but dont worry they are looking to see if there is another job for you. But then later i got an email to say i have not got a job...ðŸ˜¥ðŸ˜¥. I just cant believe from going from a congratulations to a NO .... ðŸ˜­ðŸ˜­ðŸ˜­ðŸ˜­ðŸ˜­   Thank you...Sainsbury s.

column4: Hi  your Black Friday timer on the Website says the sale starts in 5hrs 40mins and is  In Store Only  but the store opens at 7am  which 12hrs 40 mins away.... so which is it ?
column9: But that makes no sense... even if Friday starts at 00:00, the sales don't start until the store open so whats the point of the timer.  It'll hit 00:00 at midnight and nothing will happen; queues won't have formed, doors won't open, any potential stampedes won't kick-off.....  we'll all be asleep (maybe not all).  Black Friday is all about the sales, which start when the doors open, not the actual day - doh!!!

column4: Hi. I tired to find an email contact for you but failed. I have just gone to my Nectar account to find it has been closed. I have been using my card for a long time but have never redeemed any points. I find it extraordinary that you would close an account without any forewarning. I have now registered for a new one but am upset that I have lost all previous points. Please can you advise.
column9: Sorry about this Bryony! The best thing would be to speak with our Nectar team on 0800 636262, option 1. They'll be best equipped to assist. Faiza.

column4: Dear Sainsburys  As I was leaving your store  I passed the  food bank  box and again felt cross with myself for not remembering to buy anything for the local food bank. I am not ashamed to say that it slipped my mind. Being in a hurry to pick my children up  I couldn t return for an item and promised myself that I would pick up something next time. However  the reality of it is... that next time I will probably do exactly the same thing! It got me thinking......... what if you had a designated shelf or two especially for foodbank items near each check out? You could have one member of staff who is in charge of contacting the foodbank to see what items are specifically needed (as I am sure this differs in each locality) and place these items near each till with a noticable  food bank  sign. I (and many others) would be sure to notice and pick up an item before we paid. The foodbank in each area would also recieve items that they need. Just an idea! Thanks for reading!
column9: Please do this at badger farm Winchester store too!

There was a display of biscuits, tinned goods and other foods as you arrived , for customers  to choose from, pay for with their own shopping and then place in crates to be collected by the Food Bank.. Very simple and a good quantity was collected on the day, hope they do it again

column4: Dear Sainsburys  As I was leaving your store  I passed the  food bank  box and again felt cross with myself for not remembering to buy anything for the local food bank. I am not ashamed to say that it slipped my mind. Being in a hurry to pick my children up  I couldn t return for an item and promised myself that I would pick up something next time. However  the reality of it is... that next time I will probably do exactly the same thing! It got me thinking......... what if you had a designated shelf or two especially for foodbank items near each check out? You could have one member of staff who is in charge of contacting the foodbank to see what items are specifically needed (as I am sure this differs in each locality) and place these items near each till with a noticable  food bank  sign. I (and many others) would be sure to notice and pick up an item before we paid. The foodbank in each area would also recieve items that they need. Just an idea! Thanks for reading!
column9: Hi Rosie, great idea! I do the same thing and always feel guilty but it seems too much hassle to go back once you've paid. Hope they implement this x

column4: Called into sainsburys carlisle today to get a couple of bits. Noticed the now tv free view boxes were on offer but none on shelf. How ridiculous...I didn t expect any further discount and was happy to pay the Â£15 but was told no its for tomorrow sorry. What a stupid policy. You have stock sitting there but won t sell me it! Not very impressed .

column9: Hi Claire, we don't have it on DVd unfortunately. However, you may be interested in the The Greatest Gift Kit (film kit) is a box set for kids to direct their very own animated Christmas film. If he likes the advert so much, he may enjoy being a part of making is very own version. Faiza.

column4: Well Sainsbury s  it appears I have yet another bone to pick with you! However  on this occasion it is regarding a more serious matter. This evening  myself and my sister were putting air in my car tyres at the Sainsbury s petrol station attached to the superstore in Uxbridge on Coldharbour Lane. However next to us  we spotted a cyclist going passed  although unfortunately for him  a drain cover had broken meaning the drain was uncovered and his wheel got caught and subsequently he flew over the handle bars! We rushed over towards him  and whilst my sister pulled the bike off of him I rang for an ambulance. He was able to sit himself up  however he had gone face first  broke his helmet and smashed his glasses  so as you can imagine there was a lot of blood! I stayed with him whilst my sister went into the store to get more help  but she was met by a member of staff who simply handed her the emergency first aid bag and then wandered off. My sister then had to administer minimal treatment herself until the emergency response arrived! Once the emergency response came we moved inside and were given paperwork to fill out. For the rest of the duration from which the accident took place and the patient being taken to hospital in the ambulance  there was very minimal and poor communication from the 3 members of staff who we met. And we did all the paperwork! We asked the patient the questions  we got his details  we stayed with him until he was taken to the hospital  and we took his bike back to his address where his mum was very appreciative for all we did for him. And that s ok for us  we are both disabled and we appreciate what it means to have someone stop  stay  talk with and help in any way possible when an accident happens. But your staff were useless  showed no empathy and didn t care - that s just wrong. I cannot tell you how disappointed I am in Sainsbury s  for not taking care in their outside environment which tonight therefore resulted in an accident. I am also disappointed about their entire attitude towards the patient  ourselves and the emergency response staff on scene. We were in disbelief!!  I want to see that the drains are fixed so that this accident does not happen to someone else  and I want to make sure ALL staff who work for Sainsbury s are first aid trained. In the event of a life/death emergency  tonight  your staffs inability to deal with an emergency could result in someone s death...  I also hope you contact the patient himself and ensure you look after him well!! #SortItSainsburys ðŸ‘ŽðŸ¼
column9: Thank you Marion! We're just so glad we were there to help this poor guy when he needed it! We left our contact details with his family and hopefully we'll here how he is soon xx

He was able to sit himself up  however he had gone face first  broke his helmet and smashed his glasses  so as you can imagine there was a lot of blood! I stayed with him whilst my sister went into the store to get more help  but she was met by a member of staff who simply handed her the emergency first aid bag and then wandered off. My sister then had to administer minimal treatment herself until the emergency response arrived! Once the emergency response came we moved inside and were given paperwork to fill out. For the rest of the duration from which the accident took place and the patient being taken to hospital in the ambulance  there was very minimal and poor communication from the 3 members of staff who we met. And we did all the paperwork! We asked the patient the questions  we got his details  we stayed with him until he was taken to the hospital  and we took his bike back to his address where his mum was very appreciative for all we did for him. And that s ok for us  we are both disabled and we appreciate what it means to have someone stop  stay  talk with and help in any way possible when an accident happens. But your staff were useless  showed no empathy and didn t care - that s just wrong. I cannot tell you how disappointed I am in Sainsbury s  for not taking care in their outside environment which tonight therefore resulted in an accident. I am also disappointed about their entire attitude towards the patient  ourselves and the emergency response staff on scene. We were in disbelief!!  I want to see that the drains are fixed so that this accident does not happen to someone else  and I want to make sure ALL staff who work for Sainsbury s are first aid trained. In the event of a life/death emergency  tonight  your staffs inability to deal with an emergency could result in someone s death...  I also hope you contact the patient himself and ensure you look after him well!! #SortItSainsburys ðŸ‘ŽðŸ¼
column9: I'm really sorry about this Lizzie, can you confirm the exact time this happened? Did this happen on Sainsbury's grounds? Did you catch the name of the colleague who gave you the first aid kit? Steven

column4: Would just like to say a huge thank you to Calum who works in the clothing department at Sainsbury s Darnley store.  My mum recently visited the store and tried on a few pairs of gloves but couldn t decide which gloves to buy. On returning home she realised my dad s wedding  ring which she has worn since he past away many years ago was missing.  As you can imagine the ring has huge sentimental value and is irreplaceable  Mum returned to the shop and a lovely assistant whos name she couldn t remember  helped to looked for the ring but with no success. They  were very sympathetic and Tracey from customer service  took my mum s phone number and said they would check with their colleague who works in the department and get back to her. When mum returned home their was a message on her phone from Calum to say he had found the ring and has left it at the customer service desk along with a new pair of gloves with their complements. What a lovely gesture and made my mum s day. Excellent customer service please pass this on to your Darnley store.
column9: Awww great happy ending, could imagine how stressed she would of been â¤ðŸ’” well done to that team in sainsburys xx

column4: I am fuming with the staff of your Wilson street store in Middlesbrough. My father is employed to clean the car park and the rest of the outside space of the store. While he was working on the morning 22.11.16 he was suffering from chest pains  he asked a lot of staff that where starting their shift if they could help him as he was ill. Each staff member just walked past my father and give him a dirty look. My dad was suffering a heart attack at the time he was asking for help and if only one member of staff stopped and spoke to him he would have been diagnosed of being ill and sent to hospital a lot earlier.  I assume that staff at this store is first aid trained. My dad couldnâ€™t either find any staff from the cleaning team to report that he was ill and was leaving the premises to seek medical help.  He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.
column9: Shocking how dare they do that to an employer i think as a member of family tell every one how unprofessional that store is . And what they have done to youre dad xx

column9: Sainsbury's has a duty of care towards all staff &  contractors employed to carry out work at the stores premises and car park area.  to be ignored by staff members warrants a full internal investigation and a HSE investigation.  your dad has every right to see Sainsbury's policy on first aid treatment by on duty qualified staff.  if your dad is a contractor working on a Sainsbury's site then he has the same rights to first aid response by Sainsbury's qualified First Aid staff as he would if he employed directly by Sainsbury's.   if staff ignored him whilst he was ill then the CCTV should be reviewed and those staff members should be investigated individually  and their and the companies response to be made available to your dad under the Data Protection Act as it concerns your dad and his name will be the centre of the incident.   i hope your dad makes a good speedy recovery.

column9: i own a business and i have closed my business a few times to respond to people falling over or becoming ill outside in the street and sought emergency medical aid, compassion isn't a gift bestowed on someone when they feel like it, it is something we are born with and should be used when asked to help someone.  i am also a lifeboat volunteer crewmember and i close my business to answer call outs when my pager bleeps.24/7 even if it means a risk of injury or putting my own life on the line to help save others.  i don't have to come back but i have to go out and do my best.  i always say there maybe someone anywhere at anytime on land or at sea who urgency of help maybe more important than our needs at that moment in time.

column9: Rachael  in your letter mention your dad left the Sainsbury site to seek medical aid thus because of the staff failings  he contravened company Fire Safety Policy, if the fire alarms  had gone off in the store the roll call would have regarded him as missing and the fire brigade would have committed at least four firefighters into the building possibly into a dangerous situation to search for him, this would been no fault or liability  on your dad  it would have been down pure company staff failings to respond to his initial needs.

My dad was suffering a heart attack at the time he was asking for help and if only one member of staff stopped and spoke to him he would have been diagnosed of being ill and sent to hospital a lot earlier.  I assume that staff at this store is first aid trained. My dad couldnâ€™t either find any staff from the cleaning team to report that he was ill and was leaving the premises to seek medical help.  He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.
column9: if your family  don't mind and with your dads permission if he wishes, could you let us know in very brief terms how you get on with Sainsbury's but we all  respect your family and dads privacy if he wishes not to release any correspondence from the company.  as you can see this has upset and angered many people.

column9: for a full investigation write to Sainsbury's  Chairman David Tyler  and Chief Executive Michael Coupe directly and by recorded delivery and ask for a full internal investigation into the staffs conduct and failures, giving the date and times of when your dad asked for help. in your letter make the Chairman and the CE personally responsible for the investigation and no one else. the Chairman and CE hold the overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff working at the company sites and for the policies to be adhered to when an incident occurs.  going through the facebook page won't get to the Chairman or CE  as it will dealt with by very junior staff, this incident and it's failings must be brought to the attention of the Chairman and CE.  your dad will need to write a statement or have someone write it in his words and he needs to sign it.  Sainsbury Stores Support Centre, 33 Holburn, London, EC1N 2HT.  your dad's plight and being ignored has upset and angered me, i cannot understand that no staff helped your dad and he drove home whilst suffering small cardiac arrests so as to be able to get emergency medical aid.   i am Claire Mcnamara-Myers cousin and i read this on her FB page a few times to make sure i had read it correctly as i find it hard to  believe that no one showed your dad any compassion.

I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.

Each staff member just walked past my father and give him a dirty look. My dad was suffering a heart attack at the time he was asking for help and if only one member of staff stopped and spoke to him he would have been diagnosed of being ill and sent to hospital a lot earlier.  I assume that staff at this store is first aid trained. My dad couldnâ€™t either find any staff from the cleaning team to report that he was ill and was leaving the premises to seek medical help.  He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.
column9: Hopes he's ok  x

column9: my advice to any one with employment problems or customer related problems with a company, always write to the Head Office and only write to the Chairman or CE make the situation their problem. if you speak to a local manage you don't always get very far, serious problems is the head of company problem. the person at the top is  responsible for everyone in the company chain whether they are staff, contractors or customers.  a Chairman or CE  donot like and are not trained to deal with employees or customers on a personal level but once you have their personal attention and you keep corresponding with that person they cannot get away from you and they want the situation resolving quickly and in a satisfied manner.

column9: We booked at that store two years running for a charity event Marie Curie. First year we got there it was double booked so we were not allowed on site. It takes a lot of time to get volunteers to stand in store and collect. Would not Ho near shop again. Glad your father is recovering well x

Each staff member just walked past my father and give him a dirty look. My dad was suffering a heart attack at the time he was asking for help and if only one member of staff stopped and spoke to him he would have been diagnosed of being ill and sent to hospital a lot earlier.  I assume that staff at this store is first aid trained. My dad couldnâ€™t either find any staff from the cleaning team to report that he was ill and was leaving the premises to seek medical help.  He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.
column9: Shame on you Sainsbury and your heartless staff. Where is your duty of care? I hope your dad makes a good recovery.

My dad was suffering a heart attack at the time he was asking for help and if only one member of staff stopped and spoke to him he would have been diagnosed of being ill and sent to hospital a lot earlier.  I assume that staff at this store is first aid trained. My dad couldnâ€™t either find any staff from the cleaning team to report that he was ill and was leaving the premises to seek medical help.  He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.

Each staff member just walked past my father and give him a dirty look. My dad was suffering a heart attack at the time he was asking for help and if only one member of staff stopped and spoke to him he would have been diagnosed of being ill and sent to hospital a lot earlier.  I assume that staff at this store is first aid trained. My dad couldnâ€™t either find any staff from the cleaning team to report that he was ill and was leaving the premises to seek medical help.  He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.
column9: Out of order give Lenny my regards and a speedy recovery mate

He had to drive home while suffering from a heart attack. This could have caused a serious accident or tradegy where people lost lifes. When at home my mother saw how bad he was and rang his G.P. His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.

His G.P then rang for an ambulance to take him to hospital  when he was assessed by the paramedic of suffering a heart attack and he was blue lighted straight to James Cook hospital  where he was observed by the wonderful staff from the hospital  that afternoon he had to undertake an operation on his heart and had to have two stents fitted. I am really glad my father received the right treatment and is recovering well with the support of the hospital and his family.  I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.
column9: I hope your father has a speedy recovery ,I must say the staff in our Tindale Store at Bishop Auckland and especially the staff in our local Newton Aycliffe store are brilliant ,this needs looking into ,I know they try to train them to the highest possible standards ,I have to agree with Gem Medd ,if they treat the colleague in this manner how would they treat a customer ??

I will never shop in Sainsburyâ€™s ever again and hope a lot more people will follow suit because of the rotten treatment of my father suffered in his hour of need.

column4: Tesco and Waitrose have committed to remove John West tuna from their shelves if they donâ€™t clean up their act. Why is Sainsburyâ€™s not doing the same??? Earlier this year  Greenpeace travelled to the Indian Ocean to investigate unsustainable fishing practices and found destructive fishing devices - that kill sharks and turtles and countless other marine life - belonging to Thai Union  the company who owns John West. Yet Sainsburyâ€™s continues to ignore the publicâ€™s please and still puts profits before sound business practices and integrity. Is it not important to your company to protect our environment and safeguard our planet for our future generations? Our planet is in peril because of ruthless  reckless industrial and corporate giants such as yourself who donâ€™t care about anything but the bottom line. When are you going to take up your responsibility as a major business and do what is right and ethical??

column4: Tesco and Waitrose have committed to remove John West tuna from their shelves if they donâ€™t clean up their act. Why is Sainsburyâ€™s not doing the same??? Earlier this year  Greenpeace travelled to the Indian Ocean to investigate unsustainable fishing practices and found destructive fishing devices - that kill sharks and turtles and countless other marine life - belonging to Thai Union  the company who owns John West. Yet Sainsburyâ€™s continues to ignore the publicâ€™s please and still puts profits before sound business practices and integrity. When are you going to take up your responsibility as a major business and do what is right and ethical??

column4: Just want to say what fantastic service I received at your Hill Barton store yesterday. I was shopping on the double up offer and being very indecisive which would have been fine if I wasn t with my 3 year old son  he was getting a bit fed up when along came Thomas he spoke to us  was very engaging and secretly asked me if my son could have a sweet!! This of course made my sons day and made my shopping trip all the more easy. Once at the till Thomas came over again and chatted to us and gave my son a lolly  needless to say he asked if we could go to sainsburys again today! It s little things like this that make a huge difference to parents trying to shop with children. Please pass on our thanks to Thomas  we are regular visitors to the store and it s always a pleasure to be served by him.

column4: After moving into my own home almost 11 years ago I have been a loyal Sainsburyâ€™s shopper... Roughly Â£100 - Â£130 a week  every week for the past 11 years. As neither me nor my husband drive and now with a 6 week old baby the odd online shop has been a lifesaver and I am normally very happy with the Sainsburyâ€™s service. . However this is the 2nd time I have had reason to complain in the last 4 months. Last night I placed an online order to be delivered today and I am really unhappy with the state my groceries have arrived in. There was a broken custard pot  which I can forgive as accidents do happen. But the custard had leaked out all over the delivery even onto items in other bags. The driver did say he would refund the custard but as I continued to unpack I came across more and more that was covered in custard. In total 14 items had to be washed before I could put them away. In addition to that my sons yoghurts in a different bag had burst or been split too and in a 3rd bag our eggs were broken. Your delivery driver realising that I was becoming more and more unsatisfied only offered the solution of returning my whole order for a full refund. But at this time of night I donâ€™t fancy taking a 6 year old and a 6 week old out to the supermarket to do a weekâ€™s shopping I had already done online and already paid for. I didnâ€™t want to return my whole shopâ€¦ I wanted my whole shop to arrive in a clean usable condition. Too much to ask for???? After your driver left and I continued to unpack my bags I found all my fresh meat looked as though it had been thrown around the store prior to delivery and there was also raw meat products in the same bags as things like cheese and lunch box snacksâ€¦. Having worked in the food industry and another main UK supermarket I know this is NOT standard practice nor is it acceptable to store or pack raw meat with other products. Then I found a tray of chicken that has been split open and had raw meat hanging out of it. A red pepper that had clearly been put loose in a bag with heavier items and a great big hole I my Bakewell tart that was for a dinner I am having with my grandparents when they come to visit our new baby (not a very impressive dessert especially without any custard)  broken and snapped asparagus and the list goes on. This is not the kind of service I expect and I will not tolerate it either. I am not stuck with some unusable items  some dirty items and some missing items that I will have to go out and buy making the time I thought I had saved shopping online a complete waste of time. Plus I am going to be out of pocked on a taxi to the store and I dread to think how I will push and buggy and a trolley around the store. All in all this has been a very unpleasant experience. I am really disappointed.
column9: So after initial contact simply asking for my order number nothing but silence from sainsburys... However I have found the broken yoghurts that I asked the driver to return dumped in my flower pots in the front garden and now recieved an automatic e-mail saying that 3 or the 5 items I asked him to return and refund have been refunded because he was obviously too lazy to log the return of all 5 items.

But at this time of night I donâ€™t fancy taking a 6 year old and a 6 week old out to the supermarket to do a weekâ€™s shopping I had already done online and already paid for. I didnâ€™t want to return my whole shopâ€¦ I wanted my whole shop to arrive in a clean usable condition. Too much to ask for???? After your driver left and I continued to unpack my bags I found all my fresh meat looked as though it had been thrown around the store prior to delivery and there was also raw meat products in the same bags as things like cheese and lunch box snacksâ€¦. Having worked in the food industry and another main UK supermarket I know this is NOT standard practice nor is it acceptable to store or pack raw meat with other products. Then I found a tray of chicken that has been split open and had raw meat hanging out of it. A red pepper that had clearly been put loose in a bag with heavier items and a great big hole I my Bakewell tart that was for a dinner I am having with my grandparents when they come to visit our new baby (not a very impressive dessert especially without any custard)  broken and snapped asparagus and the list goes on. This is not the kind of service I expect and I will not tolerate it either. I am not stuck with some unusable items  some dirty items and some missing items that I will have to go out and buy making the time I thought I had saved shopping online a complete waste of time. Plus I am going to be out of pocked on a taxi to the store and I dread to think how I will push and buggy and a trolley around the store. All in all this has been a very unpleasant experience. I am really disappointed.

column4: Dear Sainsbury s   I visited my local store (Sainsburys  Colchester avenue  Cardiff) On Sunday 20th November  to take advantage of your double points promotion. My Boyfriend and I are moving in together this month  and so we had saved up our points all year so we could get some new house stuff. We spoke to a member of staff who told us we could double up Â£25 to Â£50 worth of points. After much deliberation  we decided to spend our points on a toaster and kettle. When we then went to redeem our points  another staff member  Rob  was serving. He explained that there was a Â£40 limit on the points. Rob was really helpful and polite  when scanning the toaster we discovered it was on sale anyway  which only left us with Â£5 over the Â£40. Then Rob offered as a gesture of  goodwill  he could take the last Â£5 off  so we could still get both the items with our points. I want to say thank you so much to Rob  you really made our day! Amazing customer service!
column9: Hi there Emma, it's great to hear my colleague was so helpful to you! I've had your comments fed back to the store manager to have a look at. Thanks for getting in touch about this. I hope everything goes smoothly with the move! Debs

column4: To the women who was on shift in the petrol station at Sainsburys in Tamworth at 7.45am on Thursday 17th November I would just like to let you know that my little boy has just today being discharged from hospital after transferred via ambulance to Walsgrave Hospital with suspected pnemonia.  My little boy took ill on Thursday so I phoned 111 who advised me to take him to the hospital. After seeing my little boy so poorly and being physically sick I jumped in my car and headed for A&E. On the way I noticed my petrol light was on so I pulled in to get fuel. I put Â£25.00 of fuel in and went to pay to find I hadn t picked my purse up...(Yes I should have checked I had means of payment which I thought was in my little boy bag however in the haste of the moment I must have forgot to pick it up as it wasn t!)  After informing the young women at the counter who was very  helpful  in informing me it was a criminal offence and that she would be calling the police who would Pursue me immediately I told her I had to leave and couldn t wait the 30 mins for her to ring the police and carry out the checks etc. I offered for my husband (who was 78 miles away racing down the m6 to meet me at the hospital) to pay over the phone via our joint account to which she replied it wasn t acceptable and someone needed to bring me the money or my purse. I then attempted to return to my car to get my little boy at which point she very loudly told me I couldn t and had to remain in the shop. Obviously I went to get my little boy out of the car to find him being violently sick everywhere. After returning to the shop and cleaning him up the best I could I told her I would be calling the police to tell them I was having to drive off and told them they would find me at the the A&E department. To the very kind young gentleman who offered to lend me the money to enable me to leave to take my little boy to get the help he needed thank you so much. You really are a life saver! I didn t know this chap from Adam and despite offering him my name  address and tel num he just took my num and said he would call me later - which he did and my husband left the money with the neighbour ready for him to collect.  Once the other women working in the Petrol station saw how poorly my little boy was they were very apologetic asking if they could do anything and apologising for adding stress to what was a very stressful situation for me. I know the staff have protocols to follow and I know I could have been pulling a fast one however they could clearly see I was distressed  upset and hopefully genuine. This is my local store  I hold a nectar card which although I didn t have on me it was in my purse I m sure she could have found me on the system somehow.  After speaking to people about my experience they have all said that if they have done it before or knew of someone who has done it they have had to fill a form in and take payment within 24 hours or face being reported to the police. Thankfully after being on a enebaliser for 2 days and then oxygen for a further 24 hours  2 chest X-rays  inhalers and antibiotics my little boy had a severe chest infection and bronchitis. Thankfully after his 2nd chest X-ray this morning it was confirmed he didn t have pneumonia.  We are now finally home but I would just like to show my sheer disgust to the young women in the petrol station that morning. I know I was 100% at fault for having no means of payment on me but there was certainly a better way of dealing with the matter in question! I will be speaking with the store manager but anyone in the same circumstances if you forget your purse expect to be embarrassed in front of a shop full of people and  spoken to by the staff of Sainsburys like a child!
column9: What a shame i wasn't offered this - I offered to give my name, address vehicle reg, tel num but she hasn't having none of it and said she was going into the back to call the police!

After informing the young women at the counter who was very  helpful  in informing me it was a criminal offence and that she would be calling the police who would Pursue me immediately I told her I had to leave and couldn t wait the 30 mins for her to ring the police and carry out the checks etc. I offered for my husband (who was 78 miles away racing down the m6 to meet me at the hospital) to pay over the phone via our joint account to which she replied it wasn t acceptable and someone needed to bring me the money or my purse. I then attempted to return to my car to get my little boy at which point she very loudly told me I couldn t and had to remain in the shop. Obviously I went to get my little boy out of the car to find him being violently sick everywhere. After returning to the shop and cleaning him up the best I could I told her I would be calling the police to tell them I was having to drive off and told them they would find me at the the A&E department. To the very kind young gentleman who offered to lend me the money to enable me to leave to take my little boy to get the help he needed thank you so much. You really are a life saver! I didn t know this chap from Adam and despite offering him my name  address and tel num he just took my num and said he would call me later - which he did and my husband left the money with the neighbour ready for him to collect.  Once the other women working in the Petrol station saw how poorly my little boy was they were very apologetic asking if they could do anything and apologising for adding stress to what was a very stressful situation for me. I know the staff have protocols to follow and I know I could have been pulling a fast one however they could clearly see I was distressed  upset and hopefully genuine. This is my local store  I hold a nectar card which although I didn t have on me it was in my purse I m sure she could have found me on the system somehow.  After speaking to people about my experience they have all said that if they have done it before or knew of someone who has done it they have had to fill a form in and take payment within 24 hours or face being reported to the police. Thankfully after being on a enebaliser for 2 days and then oxygen for a further 24 hours  2 chest X-rays  inhalers and antibiotics my little boy had a severe chest infection and bronchitis. Thankfully after his 2nd chest X-ray this morning it was confirmed he didn t have pneumonia.  We are now finally home but I would just like to show my sheer disgust to the young women in the petrol station that morning. I know I was 100% at fault for having no means of payment on me but there was certainly a better way of dealing with the matter in question! I will be speaking with the store manager but anyone in the same circumstances if you forget your purse expect to be embarrassed in front of a shop full of people and  spoken to by the staff of Sainsburys like a child!
column9: Danni Wood glad to hear he is better my friend 4 week Old daughter is In with the same xx
