column4: Dear Sainsbury s   Every year I look forward to your Christmas advert and I m sad to say this year s advert has really dissapointed me. Don t get me wrong I LOVE James Corden however the warm Christmas message I have become used to just wasn t there.   I m sure from your First World War advert of 2014 you understand how much of an impact you can make from your Christmas advert. The message you bring can help make our world a greater place by raising money and awareness. Unfortunately you haven t done that this year.   I have written you a Christmas advert for 2017 that I hope you enjoy.... let s bring awareness to homelessness next Christmas.   It opens up with people shopping  laughing  having coffee through the window of the shop.  A song is sung all accoutically and slow. There s a little girl about 8 years old but she isn t looking at the bright christmas tree or the toys in the shop  she sees the homeless people  the people who are really struggling.   The little girl comes home and writes her list to santa  Dear santa  for christmas this year please help people who don t have homes  the parents see the list and are overcome with emotion.   The shot goes to a few homeless people waking up to cards sitting on their rucksack/trolley. They open the cards and tears roll down their cheeks.   Back to the little girl  she s setting the table  opening the last window in her advent calender. She s sad  she got a bike for christmas but her wish didn t come true.   The doorbell rings.   She perks up... who could this be?  In come the homeless people and she had the biggest smile on her face.   There s a montage of eating christmas dinner  pulling crackers and general warm happiness.  The advert ends with the little girl looking out the window to see Santa s sleigh flying past and she whispers  thanks Santa    Christmas is for sharing   Now obviously I am not a writer but you could do something to help raise awareness. When you release that advert you could make sure every store has a donation box for food banks  the song sung in the advert could be a charity single raising money for a homeless charity  sell hats/scarves/gloves cheap to be donated.   You have the power to raise awareness with your Christmas advert... Use it.   Thanks for reading  Gemma (former Sainsburys employee)
column9: Haha its only a quick example of how Christmas adverts can do a lot of good... this year was a waste :-( thanks hun xx

column9: Given that the charity is great ormond street hospital I think that while that dad was at work, rushing around trying to do everything they should have shown the other parent at the bedside of another child, the family being split and then on Christmas all the family being in the parent accommodation so they can all be on the ward together as a family, show the presents that the kids are given, Santa coming round, the staff bringing in board games and all the things that the hospital does to make Christmas special in the circumstances. One of the best Christmases I had was on one of the wards at GOSH, bought home the true meaning of Christmas and made me feel grateful, not only at what I had but also being lucky enough to be part of the families celebrations. Your idea is fab though, maybe they'll bring you in to do next year's one.

column4: Since you are a leading  very ethical  family company  your advertising links with racist and fascist  newspapers  such as the Daily Mail and Daily Express is inexcusable as well as bad for business. Please drop them and save your reputation.
column9: I've never bought the Mail or Express.  The aim is to stop companies giving them advertising revenue.  The Mail is historically fascist: see their pre-war support for Hitler & Mussolini. This is just a template I dashed off for use in an email storm.  It is a kind of shorthand to pack a punch on Sainsbury's FB page.  It is not worth producing a long, reasoned letter with scholarly footnotes for this purpose.  Go on!  Write a better one and send it!

column4: Since you are a leading  very ethical  family company  your advertising links with racist and fascist  newspapers  such as the Daily Mail and Daily Express is inexcusable as well as bad for business. Please drop them and save your reputation.
column9: If Sainsbury's pull those papers from their shelves as a result of public pressure, people will rightly see it as intimidation from the left suppressing their outlet of free speech. It just makes a bad problem even worse. As for ""it's bad for business"", you do realise they fly off the shelves right? They're disgusting papers, but they're very good for business indeed.

column4: Your email function on the website doesn t seem to be working so here is the message I tried to send!  I am writing to inform you that I will no longer be shopping at Sainsburyâ€™s until your company withdraws all advertising from The Daily Mail newspaper. I am disappointed to hear that you will not reconsider your advertising policy unlike the Co-Operative Supermarket  who are currently reviewing its advertising partners due to concerns from customers. Lego also announced on Saturday that they will withdraw their advertising campaigns in The Daily Mail which has gained the company a huge amount of respect and gratitude from its customers. Thousands of positive comments can be read on their Facebook page and Twitter account. What a great endorsement for Lego!  The Daily Mail and The Mail on Sundayâ€™s editorial have behaved despicably in recent years by promoting messages of hatred towards vulnerable and minority groups.  Their style of reporting is deliberately meant to create fear and resentment; very little of what is printed in this publication is based on fact. For example  their recent coverage of child refugees being transported from the Calais â€œjungleâ€ involved the use of an inaccurate age-recognition app in order to determine their ages with the implication being that grown adults were pretending to be minors in order to gain access to the UK. Such treatment of young people is completely inappropriate  not to mention the fact that it negates The UN Convention on The Rights of The Child. Additionally  as a school teacher who works with many young people who happen to be asylum seekers and refugees  I find this treatment of young people personally upsetting.  It is not only ethnic minorities that are victim to the publicationâ€™s despicable treatment. In 2013  courts ruled that school teacher  Lucy Meadows committed suicide in March earlier that year  as a result of her gender reassignment being outed by the national press. Michael Singleton  the coroner for Blackburn  Hyndburn and Rossendale  described the Daily Mail as having carried out a campaign of  ridicule and humiliation  as well as character assassination  of the young woman. The style of reporting adopted by the paper is actively ruining peopleâ€™s lives and such hate campaigns should not be funded by a well-respected British company such as yours.  It is clear to me that the vitriol and hostility displayed in The Daily Mail is immediately at odds with your company values  particularly those promoted in your advertising campaigns which celebrate ideas of peace  togetherness and the acceptance of difference. The Daily Mail seeks to deliberately create divisions between various groups of people in our society which is of great concern considering the recent rise in hate crimes in the United Kingdom. Wouldnâ€™t you agree that being associated with this newspaper could harm the image of your brand and that advertising in their publications could be counter-productive in the long-term?  I understand that retailers sometimes do not feel the need to question their advertisersâ€™ political view but I feel that the blatant hostility shown towards refugees and Asylum Seekers by The Mailâ€™s editorial goes beyond politics. I am fully aware that all publications are within their rights to express political and ideological bias but I feel in the case of the newspaper in question  they have gone too far and are consistently breaking codes of conduct without facing the consequences. As an advertiser for the newspaper  Sainsburyâ€™s has the influence to encourage our press to change for the better and help restore a sense common decency which sadly seems to have evaporated in recent years as far as the tabloid press are concerned.  I sincerely hope that Sainsburyâ€™s will review how and where it advertises. Until then  I will not be spending money in any of your stores and will continue to make public my views on the subject.  Many thanks    Anwen Ebenezer

column4: I have just spoken to my mother only to find out she s had two Â£70 parking fines whilst shopping at Sainsbury s (Westwood cross). I am absolute appalled. Sadly my mother has cancer and has limited mobility following the most recent surgery. Shopping takes time and often we have to stop and rest in your cafe before continuing.  I cannot express how shocked and disgusted I am that she is being fined Â£140 in total for our last two shopping trips. There is no way we will be back.

column4: Dear Sainsbury s  Coming to the end of a long week at work  and having spent a wonderful weekend with my family it dawned upon me that I had forgotten to do the weekly shop. The wife was furious and my young son had to resort to foraging for nuts and seeds in the back garden for his lunch (he s only 1  but he ll out-forage me every day of the week).   What could I do to right this terrible wrong my incompetence had bestowed upon my family?   *Light bulb moment*   I had a Â£10 off voucher when I did my shopping online (on the condition that I used it before 19/11/16 and spent over Â£50). Now  I have checked the date several times in the last few hours and according to my... Er  the wife s  Justin Bieber calendar - it is still 13/11/16  so the overseers of time are on my side.  YES!  I shrieked. The wife briefly looked away from MasterChef long enough to give me a deathly stare  as she sat hungry in a grocery-less house.  The only caveat remaining would be that I need to spend over Â£50  and let me tell you  I shall do that with gusto and ease. If only there were a scenario requiring me to spend under Â£50 - now that would be a challenge  with my young son clicking  add to trolley  for the 17th time on a pack of drawstring bin liners. I like bin liners as much as the next man (maybe more) but that s a little too many even for me.  I digress.  I had loaded all of my groceries into my trolley and proceeded to checkout.  I will be a hero   I thought smugly. This was all going too well. I declared to my wife that I had solved the problem and that soon we would be basking in cupboards full of non-perishables and fresh fruit/vegetables. She smiled. A SMILE!! My son gave me a high-five. Wow. I was a demigod. I was Epaphus  or Helen of Troy. It is a weekend after all - don t judge me  And then it all came crashing down. I was greeted with the terrible news that my voucher had expired. How could this be? I had met all the required criteria. How would I break the news to the family that our shopping had all of a sudden become more expensive?  Crestfallen and defeated  I turned the laptop off. I am but a man - a mortal man who can t use a voucher correctly. You are my only hope - my salvation  if you will. Can you assist me?

I will be a hero   I thought smugly. This was all going too well. I declared to my wife that I had solved the problem and that soon we would be basking in cupboards full of non-perishables and fresh fruit/vegetables. She smiled. A SMILE!! My son gave me a high-five. Wow. I was a demigod. I was Epaphus  or Helen of Troy. It is a weekend after all - don t judge me  And then it all came crashing down. I was greeted with the terrible news that my voucher had expired. How could this be? I had met all the required criteria. How would I break the news to the family that our shopping had all of a sudden become more expensive?  Crestfallen and defeated  I turned the laptop off. I am but a man - a mortal man who can t use a voucher correctly. You are my only hope - my salvation  if you will. Can you assist me?
column9: Dear Pedro, never fear! Have you made sure you don't have any exceptions in your basket? You can double check here - http://bit.ly/1FTwzm1. Leigh

column4: I bought some cakes yesterday from the London Conley store bakery counter. When I picked the box up to put on the checkout it started to bend and collapse. I managed to get it into my car in one piece securely lodged in the boot  sadly the box was such poor quality by the time I got home it had virtually collapsed completely  the strawberry tarts were unrecognisable and the strawberry syrup was all over my shopping and bag.  Took an age to clean everything up.Sainsbury need to rethink the quality of their cake boxes  before I will buy anymore.

column4: Dear Sainsbury s.   I felt the need to write a review after a recent trip to my local Sainsbury s Saltisford in Warwick on Wednesday 09th Nov @ approx 7.30pm.  I was in a rush as always but needed to stop by to check my lottery ticket and buy some stamps before heading out to see an old friend that night.   I approached the kiosk and was greeted by a big smile from your lovely colleague Sue? (Smaller lady with short blonde hair) Now this is my local JS but I haven t seen this lady working on the kiosk before.  Anyway what was intended to be a quick pit stop turned out to be one of the most heartfelt occasions..  I ve never made it public to family and friends before.. but I suffer with anxiety and I am certainly not the most confident person on the planet.. but I had made a special effort that night as I was going out for drinks with an old friend which doesn t happen often enough. Sue looked at me smiling  eyes lit up and said  well don t you look lovely  I laughed it off as I m not used to somebody being so attentive. She went on to say  you look gorgeous  I love your eye make up with that touch of glitter .. I immediately smiled back and said  thank you  that s the kindest thing a strangers said to me in a while  she waved me off and told me to have a great evening and make the most of it.  I did just that! I walked out that store with my head held higher than it has been in a long time. Suddenly I felt great again.. confident..  so I just wanted to say to Sue  thank you! It s the little things in life that matter and all it took was a 2minute conversation and she had made my week. She didn t have to say anything.. but I m glad she did.  I m a firm believer that what goes around comes around and if anything she deserves employee of the month!   Thank you for being you Sue. I loved Sainsbury s before but now I have even more reason to smile when I shop there.   â˜ºï¸
column9: Thank you. Sue is a wonderful human being and deserves every bit of praise. I wish the rest of the world would follow suit. X

I was in a rush as always but needed to stop by to check my lottery ticket and buy some stamps before heading out to see an old friend that night.   I approached the kiosk and was greeted by a big smile from your lovely colleague Sue? (Smaller lady with short blonde hair) Now this is my local JS but I haven t seen this lady working on the kiosk before.  Anyway what was intended to be a quick pit stop turned out to be one of the most heartfelt occasions..  I ve never made it public to family and friends before.. but I suffer with anxiety and I am certainly not the most confident person on the planet.. but I had made a special effort that night as I was going out for drinks with an old friend which doesn t happen often enough. Sue looked at me smiling  eyes lit up and said  well don t you look lovely  I laughed it off as I m not used to somebody being so attentive. She went on to say  you look gorgeous  I love your eye make up with that touch of glitter .. I immediately smiled back and said  thank you  that s the kindest thing a strangers said to me in a while  she waved me off and told me to have a great evening and make the most of it.  I did just that! I walked out that store with my head held higher than it has been in a long time. Suddenly I felt great again.. confident..  so I just wanted to say to Sue  thank you! It s the little things in life that matter and all it took was a 2minute conversation and she had made my week. She didn t have to say anything.. but I m glad she did.  I m a firm believer that what goes around comes around and if anything she deserves employee of the month!   Thank you for being you Sue. I loved Sainsbury s before but now I have even more reason to smile when I shop there.   â˜ºï¸
column9: Aaaaaaaah love you my kids, and scantly clad Julie Neilson thank you.   Xxx

Anyway what was intended to be a quick pit stop turned out to be one of the most heartfelt occasions..  I ve never made it public to family and friends before.. but I suffer with anxiety and I am certainly not the most confident person on the planet.. but I had made a special effort that night as I was going out for drinks with an old friend which doesn t happen often enough. Sue looked at me smiling  eyes lit up and said  well don t you look lovely  I laughed it off as I m not used to somebody being so attentive. She went on to say  you look gorgeous  I love your eye make up with that touch of glitter .. I immediately smiled back and said  thank you  that s the kindest thing a strangers said to me in a while  she waved me off and told me to have a great evening and make the most of it.  I did just that! I walked out that store with my head held higher than it has been in a long time. Suddenly I felt great again.. confident..  so I just wanted to say to Sue  thank you! It s the little things in life that matter and all it took was a 2minute conversation and she had made my week. She didn t have to say anything.. but I m glad she did.  I m a firm believer that what goes around comes around and if anything she deserves employee of the month!   Thank you for being you Sue. I loved Sainsbury s before but now I have even more reason to smile when I shop there.   â˜ºï¸

Anyway what was intended to be a quick pit stop turned out to be one of the most heartfelt occasions..  I ve never made it public to family and friends before.. but I suffer with anxiety and I am certainly not the most confident person on the planet.. but I had made a special effort that night as I was going out for drinks with an old friend which doesn t happen often enough. Sue looked at me smiling  eyes lit up and said  well don t you look lovely  I laughed it off as I m not used to somebody being so attentive. She went on to say  you look gorgeous  I love your eye make up with that touch of glitter .. I immediately smiled back and said  thank you  that s the kindest thing a strangers said to me in a while  she waved me off and told me to have a great evening and make the most of it.  I did just that! I walked out that store with my head held higher than it has been in a long time. Suddenly I felt great again.. confident..  so I just wanted to say to Sue  thank you! It s the little things in life that matter and all it took was a 2minute conversation and she had made my week. She didn t have to say anything.. but I m glad she did.  I m a firm believer that what goes around comes around and if anything she deserves employee of the month!   Thank you for being you Sue. I loved Sainsbury s before but now I have even more reason to smile when I shop there.   â˜ºï¸

column4: Dear Sainsbury s.   I felt the need to write a review after a recent trip to my local Sainsbury s Saltisford in Warwick on Wednesday 09th Nov @ approx 7.30pm.  I was in a rush as always but needed to stop by to check my lottery ticket and buy some stamps before heading out to see an old friend that night.   I approached the kiosk and was greeted by a big smile from your lovely colleague Sue? (Smaller lady with short blonde hair) Now this is my local JS but I haven t seen this lady working on the kiosk before.  Anyway what was intended to be a quick pit stop turned out to be one of the most heartfelt occasions..  I ve never made it public to family and friends before.. but I suffer with anxiety and I am certainly not the most confident person on the planet.. but I had made a special effort that night as I was going out for drinks with an old friend which doesn t happen often enough. Sue looked at me smiling  eyes lit up and said  well don t you look lovely  I laughed it off as I m not used to somebody being so attentive. She went on to say  you look gorgeous  I love your eye make up with that touch of glitter .. I immediately smiled back and said  thank you  that s the kindest thing a strangers said to me in a while  she waved me off and told me to have a great evening and make the most of it.  I did just that! I walked out that store with my head held higher than it has been in a long time. Suddenly I felt great again.. confident..  so I just wanted to say to Sue  thank you! It s the little things in life that matter and all it took was a 2minute conversation and she had made my week. She didn t have to say anything.. but I m glad she did.  I m a firm believer that what goes around comes around and if anything she deserves employee of the month!   Thank you for being you Sue. I loved Sainsbury s before but now I have even more reason to smile when I shop there.   â˜ºï¸
column9: Are you ok Jean, thank you for the message I will pm you.   X

column4: Dear Sainsbury s.   I felt the need to write a review after a recent trip to my local Sainsbury s Saltisford in Warwick on Wednesday 09th Nov @ approx 7.30pm.  I was in a rush as always but needed to stop by to check my lottery ticket and buy some stamps before heading out to see an old friend that night.   I approached the kiosk and was greeted by a big smile from your lovely colleague Sue? (Smaller lady with short blonde hair) Now this is my local JS but I haven t seen this lady working on the kiosk before.  Anyway what was intended to be a quick pit stop turned out to be one of the most heartfelt occasions..  I ve never made it public to family and friends before.. but I suffer with anxiety and I am certainly not the most confident person on the planet.. but I had made a special effort that night as I was going out for drinks with an old friend which doesn t happen often enough. Sue looked at me smiling  eyes lit up and said  well don t you look lovely  I laughed it off as I m not used to somebody being so attentive. She went on to say  you look gorgeous  I love your eye make up with that touch of glitter .. I immediately smiled back and said  thank you  that s the kindest thing a strangers said to me in a while  she waved me off and told me to have a great evening and make the most of it.  I did just that! I walked out that store with my head held higher than it has been in a long time. Suddenly I felt great again.. confident..  so I just wanted to say to Sue  thank you! It s the little things in life that matter and all it took was a 2minute conversation and she had made my week. She didn t have to say anything.. but I m glad she did.  I m a firm believer that what goes around comes around and if anything she deserves employee of the month!   Thank you for being you Sue. I loved Sainsbury s before but now I have even more reason to smile when I shop there.   â˜ºï¸

column4: Last night a large @Sainsbury s van delivering to a neighbour got lost  reversed up our drive  and hit our house. Very pleasant young man  could not have been nicer  so felt sorry for him. But amazed no one from Sainsbury s has rung us up to see how we are.
column9: Hi Frank. Really sorry about this. Is everything okay? Can you give me some info on the damage? Daryl.

column4: Last night a large @Sainsbury s van delivering to a neighbour got lost  reversed up our drive  and hit our house. Very pleasant young man  could not have been nicer  so felt sorry for him. But amazed no one from Sainsbury s has rung us up to see how we are.
column9: Sainsbury's - no I'm afraid not all ok but that will have to be up to the Sainsbury's insurers - yet to hear from them. The van wasn't even delivering to us but got lost looking for our neighbour, and reversed into our house at the end of our private drive.  We were just expecting that Sainsbury's might phone us up to check how we were. It's quite shattering to be sitting quietly in the evening and suddenly there is a loud bang as a van reverses into the house.  Only good point was the van driver who handled the situation very well.

column4: Last night a large @Sainsbury s van delivering to a neighbour got lost  reversed up our drive  and hit our house. Very pleasant young man  could not have been nicer  so felt sorry for him. But amazed no one from Sainsbury s has rung us up to see how we are.

I personally however am disgusted that my child was served under cooked food and the mere changing of the meal was not enough for me. Your thoughts please??! Many thanks

column4: My husband and I usually avoid putting messages up on social media  but once again we have been so taken aback by the kindness and generosity of the staff at Sainsbury s Upton that we must say something. Just over a week ago we paid the Upton store a visit while in England in the hope to deliver a  thank you  card to Ryan Pierce  Mike Paterson and Geraldine for their willingness to help my unwell father in-law that was in hospital recently. Not only did they deliver on that help at the time  but they went more than the extra mile....Furthermore  just when I thought that they couldn t do anymore for us  we were bowled over by the welcome we got when visiting. Ryan  Geraldine and Customer Service Manager  Brenda offered us coffee and cake  gave us two beautiful bouquets of flowers and vowed to help our unwell and ageing family with a tailored service going into the future. Ryan Pierce subsequently told us that he couldn t accept a cash gift that we wanted to give so instead bought 50 selection boxes out of it for the children who are in Arrowe Park hospital!!! It is very clear to us that Sainsbury s Upton contradicts the stereotype of large companies taking from communities  and instead shows us that community spirit and customer loyalty is at the core of their business. It is also clear that these types of people are the unsung heroes in our neighbourhoods  and this whole story is a true example of pulling together to do a good deed - even if it is outside the normal remit.  Well done AGAIN Sainsbury s!!
column9: I worked with these ladies and gentleman at upton for 22 yrs this is no one off these people go the extra mile every single day i was blessed to call these people my friends xxx

column4: After many years of loyal custom I regret to inform you that I can no longer shop with you. It s not your delicous produce  your prices or your excellent instore service. It s your advertising choices.  I wouldn t consider myself a political person but I do believe that a line has to be drawn. And when British mainstream newspapers start replicating headlines from state sponsored propaganda in NAZI GERMANY  I believe we ve probably passed that line. While most of us were apathetically not paying attention.  And so it was with great sadness that I discovered that you were spending millions of pounds on advertising in the daily mail  express and sun. For a company whose corporate commitments include  diversity and inclusion  and that supports such worthwhile causes as  humanitarian aid  through the work of family trusts such as the Linbury trust  to be funding newspapers that demand  BRITAIN MUST BAN MIGRANTS  and refer to them as  THE SWARM ON OUR STREETS  is unfathomable.   I would urge you to reconsider your advertising choices and target this budget to publications that uphold the values you claim to hold. I believe that if we  as a country  are to turn back from the dangerous path we appear to be headed down then individuals like me need to make difficult choices that in this case will see me trudging round Morrisons with a 3 year old and 1 year old rather than benefitting from your convenient home delivery. However  more significantly  companies like yourselves need to use the  scale of your business  to contribute positively to the wider world.   Please withdraw funding from the daily mail  express and sun so that I can rebuild my relationship with you because  apart from anything else  I bloody love your pizzas.
column9: I don't think Tesco or Morrisons do currently. I hope I'm right otherwise my grocery shopping may take even longer than I had hoped.

However  more significantly  companies like yourselves need to use the  scale of your business  to contribute positively to the wider world.   Please withdraw funding from the daily mail  express and sun so that I can rebuild my relationship with you because  apart from anything else  I bloody love your pizzas.

column9: No idea of the advertising rates in any paper ,  however Robbie Williams has a full page advertising his  forthcoming tour ! Am interested to know where you do plan to shop, I imagine in the run up to Christmas, every big name will be going full throttle  to  push their wares in the press.. Have a copy of yesterday's paper and Morrison's , M & S , Iceland, Boots , Asda, Lidl , Wilko  and Aldi  are  all there  --- interestingly though Sainsburys is not ,  Maybe you have a small local store where you can shop?  Personally, like many people, I would never buy The Sun, but that is down to its Hillsborough  coverage  ,  and will continue to shop  where I have always shopped..

column4: I d appreciate the brilliant customer services of Sainsbury s Wallington to be acknowledged. Starting with Lorraine who assisted me when I called and who I believe happily went the extra mile to ensure my son had the birthday present he wanted (fifa 17) and then to the staff in store. The Lady on the customer services desk and another lady on the tobacco/newspaper till. This was Thursday 10th November. They were all brilliantly helpful  cheery and polite. I hope they can be made aware that the little things can mean a lot to a stressed out panicked mother.  Many Thanks :-)
column9: It is a very nice store to shop in, always well stocked and very good staff. Elisa is wonderful.

Starting with Lorraine who assisted me when I called and who I believe happily went the extra mile to ensure my son had the birthday present he wanted (fifa 17) and then to the staff in store. The Lady on the customer services desk and another lady on the tobacco/newspaper till. This was Thursday 10th November. They were all brilliantly helpful  cheery and polite. I hope they can be made aware that the little things can mean a lot to a stressed out panicked mother.  Many Thanks :-)

column4: Shopping just arrived. Very nice driver who was most apologetic however my joint of beef for Sunday lunch has failed to materialise having been substituted for a piece of rubbish meat. I know there s nothing you can do about it it s just really annoying and massively inconvenient!!!!!!
column9: Hi Melanie, sorry about this. Our stores receive your orders on the morning of the delivery and your shopping is chosen from what's available in store. Did you accept the substitution? If you didn't our driver will have refunded you the cost of the item. Ryan.

column4: Getting frustrated  disappointed and annoyed that Sainsburys (at least in Huntingdon) seem to be removing a number of vegan products available from their stores. Last night I went to do my online order only to find that now they have removed the Sainsburys Tomato  red pepper and lentil chilled soup as well. This means there are now only 2 vegan soups in their chilled range. During the last month or so  the Sainsburys Tarka Dhal tinned soup (which was gorgeous) has been removed  as has the Swedish Glace strawberry soy icecreams (5 indivual icecreams on sticks) and the Almond Dream Salted Caramel  icecream  . At least I can get the last two from Waitrose for the moment. Also the Basic Baby Lotion has been removed and I cannot find any moisturing lotion suitable for women that has the Leaping Bunny cruelty free symbol on it. One is restriced enough when trying to buy cruelty free products but it is upsetting when the few you like and rely on disappear without warning. If you have to reduce the number of products on the shelves  try removing some of the non-vegan or vegetarian products. There are masses of them to choose from and they cannot all be wonderful sellers. If the vegan products are not moving very well  you could try a  cruelty free promotion  and put them all together in store for a short time. I am sure that many people would be willing to buy cruelty free products if they were easier to find.
column9: That would be great. Thank you

If the vegan products are not moving very well  you could try a  cruelty free promotion  and put them all together in store for a short time. I am sure that many people would be willing to buy cruelty free products if they were easier to find.
column9: Maybe the number of vegans buying those products isn't high enough  They're not likely to remove a good seller

column4: Getting frustrated  disappointed and annoyed that Sainsburys (at least in Huntingdon) seem to be removing a number of vegan products available from their stores. Last night I went to do my online order only to find that now they have removed the Sainsburys Tomato  red pepper and lentil chilled soup as well. This means there are now only 2 vegan soups in their chilled range. During the last month or so  the Sainsburys Tarka Dhal tinned soup (which was gorgeous) has been removed  as has the Swedish Glace strawberry soy icecreams (5 indivual icecreams on sticks) and the Almond Dream Salted Caramel  icecream  . At least I can get the last two from Waitrose for the moment. Also the Basic Baby Lotion has been removed and I cannot find any moisturing lotion suitable for women that has the Leaping Bunny cruelty free symbol on it. One is restriced enough when trying to buy cruelty free products but it is upsetting when the few you like and rely on disappear without warning. If you have to reduce the number of products on the shelves  try removing some of the non-vegan or vegetarian products. There are masses of them to choose from and they cannot all be wonderful sellers. If the vegan products are not moving very well  you could try a  cruelty free promotion  and put them all together in store for a short time. I am sure that many people would be willing to buy cruelty free products if they were easier to find.
column9: Many people other than vegans enjoy the soup. They have stocked it for years and seems to sell as well as their other soups. It was delicious and I expect many people buying that do not think of it as vegan, any more than when they buy the minestrone  or tomato and basil flavours .

column4: Hi  I was just wondering if Sainsburys were planning on introducing a similar thing to Tesco in regards to offering a piece of fruit to children when entering the store? We have been Tesco quite a lot recently nd my daughter loves it and works wonder in keeping her quiet & occupied whilst shopping  plus its healthier than bags of crisps or sweets being put out! The reason I ask is because we decided we were going to try Sainsbury s for the first time in a while because as a family we enjoy the quality and foods Saonsburys as to offer. We went in and my daughter ran straight for the fruit  picked up a banana and tried to open it  i had to take it off her  I was about to go buy it but queues at the kiosk and self service were really bad and couldn t spend ages queuing for a banana to then shop & queue again! So I put it back which resulted in a crazy tantrum. I m not ones foe giving in to tantrums but it made shopping impossible  I ended up leaving ðŸ™ˆ but was just a thought as it is a great idea and fab to offer something healthy to kids due to how many families that are struggling and so many children have a poor diet! Thoughts?

column4: So I just went into your Local store in Harrogate. Quite an experience/ They close at 23.00 so they were preparing for closing and putting out large delivery cages As I was stood at the chilled section one of your employees just pushed the cages along and wandered of  not controlling them. As such  three or four of these cages slammed into my leg hitting my ankle. I was in total disbelief and the only comment I got  oh sorry !!  Are you kidding me? I expect a little more after being assaulted by someone s ineptitude.  Perhaps  start store end of day closing when customers are not around as this is dangerous.  I would appreciate a response as I am not happy in the slightest. Please be aware  I have a graze at the moment on my ankle and it is sore. If it develops into a bruise I will be livid.
column9: Harrogate Leeds Road Local 55 Leeds Road, HARROGATE

column4: I wanted to say a huge thank you for the service I received today at approx 4pm in your Abbey Wood store. I was shopping with 2 children  one asleep in a pushchair and another insisting on being in a trolley. Cue a stressed mummy pushing 2 hefty unwieldy things. Firstly a security guard looked after my shopping so I could take the my daughter to the loo. Then the store manager and colleagues saw me struggling and arranged for someone to push my trolley for me  and in the meantime the manager and what appeared to be a top dog manager  helped me around the store  pushing my daughter and guiding me to the produce I needed. Once I had finished paying  one of the trolley guys saw me and helped me to the car. THANK YOU SO MUCH for helping a stressed mummy and making her smile. Xxx
column9: I know one gentleman was the store manager as his big boss was telling me it was his store. So he will know. Then I believe it was a lady called Salome who pushed my trolley (I should have written their names down). The trolley guy was telling me he had 3 kids including twins. X

column4: Good evening.   My husband was in one of your stores yesterday  and went to the cafeteria to buy a sandwich for lunch.  Unfortunately  there were none left in the cafeteria so he selected a wrap from the fridges in store and went back to the canteen where he selected a muffin and a cappuccino to have with the wrap.  He was told that he wasn t allowed to eat the wrap in the canteen (even though it was a Sainsbury s one - and bearing in mind the cafeteria had nothing to offer).  Is this normal Sainsbury s policy?  My husband ended up going away hungry.
column9: Yeah, that's what we thought.

column4: Good evening.   My husband was in one of your stores yesterday  and went to the cafeteria to buy a sandwich for lunch. My husband ended up going away hungry.
column9: Hi Anne, unfortunately we don't allow for food purchased in-store to be consumed in the cafÃ©. Part of the sales of these products contributes towards staffing, heating, facility maintenance etc however if he was purchasing some items in the cafÃ© this should have been taken into consideration! Which store were you visiting and when? I'd like to talk to the cafÃ© manager about this. Ryan.

column4: Today Sainsbury s in Colton Leeds accused my wife of being a lair. She asked for Â£30 cash back. The chap serving her didn t give it to her. She didn t notice. She left the shop and went to fill up with petrol  at the station on the same estate  and realised she hadn t got the money. She went back to the shop and explained. The assistant took her to the check out and the check out clerk said he did not recognise her. So now we have to wait for two days while the check the till. What is to stop the check out clerk from pocketing the Â£30? Nothing. Thank you Sainsbury s.
column9: I hope so to. I'll suggest this to my wife. Thank you for the thought. They have said they will check the till but this takes 2 days and if the till does not balance my wife should get her Â£30. column9: Yes they could. However the person making the claim has to have the receipt that shows the cash back transaction. In this case my wife returned in minutes. The store could reasonably ask for proof of identity of the claimant who would then be open to charges of theft/fraud. Given that the vast majority of people are honest Sanisbury's should give the customer the benefit of the doubt. We live within walking distance of this store and have done since it opened over 20 years ago. We have spent thousand and thousands of pounds there and this is how we get treated.

column9: Hi Chris, apologies for the inconvenience. I've spoken with the Commercial Manager for the store and they've confirmed that the correct process has been followed. Our tills in-store won't be cashed off until Monday, so this is why you have been advised of the wait, however I've been advised that as part of the process all CCTV records are checked as well as the till records. A member of our cash office will be in touch with you on Monday. Ryan.

column9: It hasn't been signed or initialled by either my wife or the check out clerk. I don't think they run that system any more as the last time I got cash back at the same store neither I nor the check out clerk signed the receipt. You do have to 'accept' the cash back part of the transaction before you put you pin in. However this leaves the customer vulnerable as the clerk could forget to give the money, as in this case, but guilt/error is presumed on the part of the customer. Hardly the right attitude for a customer focused, and dependent, organisation.

What is to stop the check out clerk from pocketing the Â£30? Nothing. Thank you Sainsbury s.
column9: All's well that ends well. She got her cash :D

column4: Hi Sainsburys! You recently sent out an email with a healthy eating survey attached  to get some extra Nectar points. column4: Today I have visited Sainsbury s at Marsh Mills Plymouth. It is  Armistice Day.    There was a lady selling Poppy s in the foyer  she was freezing cold and when asked told me it was Sainsbury s company policy not to allow Poppy s to be sold inside the store. So she had to stand outside.  I find this absolutely disgraceful and said as much to Customise Services. The lady at CS said it wasn t that cold in the foyer and it was heated. It was absolutely freezing.  The queue of people behind me at CS found this equally disgusting and said so.  She said she would mention it to the manager....  Sainsbury s   you should be absolutely ashamed of yourselves  to make a lady selling Poppy s stand outside in the cold when it would make no difference to your store for her to be stood inside is  disgusting.  After I had complained the lady was allowed to stand inside but for me to have to ask for this to happen is appalling and disgraceful.  Today you have lost quite a few customers. You need to review your company policies and make changes otherwise I expect you ll lose a lot more.
column9: An absolute disgrace  Shame on you Sainsburys

column9: I cannot believe this is "" company policy"" ,  simply because at my local Sainsburys ,Brentwood Essex , there has  always been a wonderful relationship with Poppy sellers .. This year is no exception, there are tables inside the store to make a large display of Poppies, and other items,  each day we have different sellers ranging from service  cadets last weekend to wonderful veterans, who  assure me that Sainsburys are proud to look after them during their shift selling poppies. We have displays of poppies hanging from the ceiling of the store, and all staff have a poppy badge sticker to attach to their name badge . Sainsburys Brentwood really could not do more to promote the sale of poppies and to look after all those involved with selling them.  Clearly the manager at Plymouth needs a firm word from someone senior,  but please do not judge all  branches by this one, I would be ashamed too, if I shopped there. All branches are not the same

column4: Sainsbury please have a word with your kids clothes buyers or designers! column4: Dear Sainsburys.  Normally I have no issue with you delivering my weekly shop.  I find  all your delivery drivers polite   helpful and friendly.  I don t often have items substituted   however   when I do   is when my problems start.  Perhaps you could give extra  common sense   training to the people you employ to pick out the shopping   as some of them clearly need it.  If I select three bags of 500g grated mature cheddar on my shopping list   does it not stand to reason that I need around 1500g of grated cheddar in total?  Yes?  No.  Apparently not.  Thank you   so much   for the three bags of 250g grated cheddar you instead sent me.  It s so very useful to me to receive half of what I required.  This may not seem like a big deal   and I agree   it s very minimal in the grand scheme of things. However  I use your service for its convenience and so that I don t have to trek out into a crowded supermarket with a potential timebomb of a 2 year old in tow. This  convenience   is now rendered moot: I have to trek out (in the snow)  to buy the rest of the cheese I need.  Nor is this the first time   if it were  I probably wouldn t be typing this right now.  In the past I have requested nappies in a certain size  only to be sent them in a completely different (and totally useless) size.  Honestly   do the people who do this job think parents want nappies that do not fit their child?  Either supply the correct size in a different brand   or don t bother at all.  Various other stupid substitutes you have sent me (and often charged me more than the original item for)  help to build the aggravation I feel right now.  I hope you take note of my points.  I expect you will not. However  next time you are looking for staff  I have a 12 year old son who displays more intelligence selecting alternative items than some of your existing trained monkeys.
column9: Hi Claire, sorry about that. I would like to log your comments back to store management. Could you PM me the order number, name on account, billing address and telephone number please? Thanks, Steve.

column4: A big thanks to Lester working out of Ellesmere Port. Delivery van had its refrigeration unit fail  which meant all sorts of chaos and it looked like we wouldn t get out food until tomorrow. With 4 hungry little mouths to feed in the morning it was going to be ugly. However  he sorted it out and delivered this evening.  Nice one. Customer service can often be measured by how you put things right when things go wrong  and Lester scored top marks for is today. Thanks.
column9: Hi Justin, happy to hear all went well! I'd like to get your comments fed back. Can you confirm your order number and full name and address on the account please? This will enable us to find out who the delivery driver was. Hayley

column4: Lovely Sainsbury s  I am highly disgruntled this evening. I hopped on down to your store in Trowbridge to buy a few bits  including my husband and I s beloved make your own pizza. They are no doubt the best value pizza s out there  total class. Our usual order? 14  thin  BBQ sauce  chicken and double peppers - simple yet effective  I think you ll agree. Oh and always wrapped so we can have it super hot and melty straight away at home. Perfection. When I got to the counter there was a young lady and a very tall gentleman who I assume was a manager of sorts due to how he was speaking to the young lady. He wrote down my order  said it would be 5 minutes  so off I went and picked up my other bits. I returned around 5 minutes later to find the tall man speaking in an ad-hoc meeting with the young lady and two other counter staff. My pizza had not been made. No bother  I know it doesn t take long to do. The young lady then proceeded to make it with me waiting. It was handed to me upside down as it was right off the vacuum thingy. I have just properly looked at it  having taken the wrapper off. Definitely not double peppers  and to my utter horror it has been made with a tomato base  not BBQ. I have this evening been severely deprived. Tomato base is just not for me; I live for a BBQ base. Now whose fault was it? The young lady being mildly berated by a manager in front of the public reading his instructions wrong  and being taken away for a mini-meet when a customer order was waiting  perhaps not checking what I had asked for? Maybe his hand writing on the notepad was quite illegible  who knows. RIP BBQ pizza I never had #firstworldproblems
column9: Hi Jayne, Firstly I'd suggest walking down as hopping is all good and well but it puts unnecessary strain upon your joint on one leg.  Now about the pizza, I know tomato base isn't the best but a healthy serving of BBQ sause from a squeezy bottle would have mustered the taste. #ResolvingFirstWorldProblems The staff speaking to each other is totally unnecessary, they should work in silence and never speak to anyone. Thanks  Sainsbury's Support Team

column4: Sainsburys online. Awful delivery time & customer service!!!  Ordered some Halloween goods from Sainsburys online 4 days b 4 Halloween. Selecting Click & collect from store.  Informed about their arrival in store late monday evening on 31/10. - 4 days later. Too late for intended purpose.  To further rub salt into the wound they were dropped to half price with an additional 25% off before they even arrived in store!  Asda & Tesco offer next day click and collect. Sainsburys took over 4 days delivering late on Halloween evening. As I can only put these up now for next year I asked if they could honour the lower price (by way of a refund) that the goods were before they even arrived in store and they just point blank refused!!  What wonderful customer service! Oh sorry they said they  can t honour the price !  More like won t! Obviously next year I ll be purchasing from Asda/Tesco next day click & collect at least they ll arrive on time.
column9: You wont need to buy next year..use the goods that arrived too late for this years celebrations...

Informed about their arrival in store late monday evening on 31/10. - 4 days later. Too late for intended purpose.  To further rub salt into the wound they were dropped to half price with an additional 25% off before they even arrived in store!  Asda & Tesco offer next day click and collect. Sainsburys took over 4 days delivering late on Halloween evening. As I can only put these up now for next year I asked if they could honour the lower price (by way of a refund) that the goods were before they even arrived in store and they just point blank refused!!  What wonderful customer service! Oh sorry they said they  can t honour the price !  More like won t! Obviously next year I ll be purchasing from Asda/Tesco next day click & collect at least they ll arrive on time.
column9: Really sorry Jon. Was this Halloween costumes you were ordering? If you PM the account holder's name, order number, email address and contact number please? I'll look into this for you. Amanda.

column4: Beware money-off coupons from Sainsbury s  giving you money off if you spend Â£40... ...so you spend well over Â£40 in store and include 6 bottles of wine (which happen to have 25% off if you buy 6)... get to checkout and you are told the coupon s not valid as it does not apply to wine with 25% off. column4: PARKING AT YOUR PENRITH STORE!  I have just came to a very unpleasant letter issues by a debt recovery company informing me I have to pay Â£130 by 17/11/2016 or they will take me to court. As you can imagine this has caused me a considerable amount of stress and worry.   I have used your store in Penrith and it s car park a number of times. However this has left a very sour taste in my mouth and has left me very reluctant to stop in your stores again.   I was only in your store earlier today and noticed that those cameras which are meant to log cars coming in and leaving your car park are actually not working!! How can you enforce a parking fine if Â£130 for a car park which hasn t been functioning properly for at least the last 2 months?   Â£130 is a very steep fine to expect your customers to pay and I think it is an unnecessary stress that you are allowing people to face. I am a single full time working mum who has to work 2 jobs to make ends meet I don t have Â£130 spare sitting around just to pay out like that.   So as one of your customers I am asking you to act up on this and sort your car park systems out and the company s that run them. As previously mentions the cameras in your Penrith branch car park have no been working for some time so how can you enforce it for one car and not another?   I would very much appreciate it if you spoke to your car parking company and got this car park fine cancelled as it has been unfairly given due to having no other letters regards this other that this 1 I have reviewed to day. I am very upset that as a big company like yourself are letting company s like this take advantage!   I hope to here from you soon.   From a very unhappy stressed and worried customer.
column9: Dont pay and if they take you to court (probably they wont) and present evidence that the cameras arent working properly. Dont let their threats intimidate you

column4: After shopping at sainsburys for years  I will sadly be changing to another supplier for my weekly shop.  After being told to try an online shop by a member of your staff at my local store  I decided to give it a try.  The fist time was ok a few things missing due to stock shortages. But the second time after receiving several  substitute  and accepting these I then found a damaged item. Which I needed the next day   After ringing your not so helpful help line was told that you wouldn t redeliver  As you weren t sending out a van for 1 item.  I own a my own business with over 8000 daily customers and if 1 asked me to change an item or redeliver I would be there within the hour!!  Your customer service is shocking!!!
column9: They haven't a clue about customer service

column4: I am very disappointed with the lack of customer service regarding Sainsbury s online delivery service and the lack of customer contact. I ordered my online grocery shop on Saturday 5th November to arrived between 9-10am on Monday night. I went through the 3D security and received the standard confirmation email and text regarding my order. However 10.20pm on Monday night I had still not received my shopping. I rang the customer service team and spoke to someone that was most unhelpful and said that the driver had already been past my home and they had rung. However I had not received any phone call or voicemail and they have delivered to my address previously. The customer service team member said my transaction had not gone through yet they had packed everything in the store to deliver to mine? As soon as there was any issue regarding my order I should have been contacted immediately. However if I had not have rung up late last night I doubt the store would have contacted me. The customer service member then said that it was too late for any more deliveries to come back out despite the fact they deliver in my area between 10pm-11pm so someone could have come back out with my shopping. I was informed and assured the manager of the local Taplow store would contact me first thing in the morning regarding this. However this never happened. This is very heartless from such a big chain superstore that a manager can not respond to my complaint. I now have no idea where my shopping is or how I will be getting my money back. One thing for sure is I will not be recommending anyone in future to use Sainbury s online delivery service as there customer service on this particular occasion was completely non existent.
column9: Sorry about that Chris! That certainly isn't the usual standard for our delivery service. I would like to follow this up for you, could you PM me the order number, name on account, billing address and telephone number please? Thanks, Steve.

column4: dont buy a microwave from sainsburys!! I bought a microwave about 1 year ago and the microwave started to smoke and catch fire whilst cooking something in it so I contacted my local sainsburys who asked me if I had the receipt to which I answeres I lost the receipt  I called customer careline to tell them and they told me to send my microwave oven to them so that they could run a quality test on the microwave. I received a letter saying that they would be in touch within 15 days. I heard nothing for about 4 weeks and then I called them and asked what had happened to my microwave. They told me they were waiting for an answer from their quality control. Well a couple of days past and they called me up and told me that some dried food was inside the microwave oven and this is why it caught light  they then told me that they could not give me another microwave. I asked them if I could have my microwave back because if it was only food that had caught light then of course it would still work and I would be able to get my microwave back  well they told me they would call me back that day to see if they could get me my microwave back  it has now been 1 week and still no telephone call or my microwave back.. Do not buy any sainsburys microwave oven grill because they are rubbish and only last 1 year avoid at all costs!!! Sainsburys also do not work with a resolution dispute service like the retail ombudsman service so you can t make a complaint to anyone but sainsburys!! So there is no point buying their products.. Thanks Sainsburys you let me down
column9: You've got the best name I've ever seen on Facebook, Mr Floobie-McDoobie.

column4: Hi just wanted to let you know we had a faulty firework. We purchased a Halloween Frankenstein fountain from CRAYFORD sainsburys on Halloween. Set it up in our back garden and lit it. Within seconds it exploded and then a small red/green flame burned for around 1 minute. Thankfully our small children were standing over 15 meters away we left the firework and went inside. Around 15 mins later we looked out the back window and the fountain was pouring out (like it should have done earlier) but on its side. The kiddies were disappointed  money was wasted but more importantly it was dangerous.
column9: Gunpowder IS dangerous.

column4: Pretty disappointed with your vouchers... You kindly sent me Â£6.00 off when you spend over Â£60.00. I got to the check out  the lady said I d spent Â£59.15. column9: Sainsbury's you're missing my point. I get those are the rules... Like I said previously. What I'm not happy about is that it excludes FIRST STAGE baby milk and the fact that if I had been advised this I would have happily spent MORE money to be able to use my voucher... Also, are the vouchers that print off from the till generic or does it go by what you buy? Like I said, why bother insulting me with a voucher off pampers size 3&4 when your system knows full well I buy size 5? And the fact I purchased two chocolate bars I didn't want! It's not about the money, I've never complained to a store in my life before. It just infuriated me that I was made to run around looking for chocolate bars for nothing, holding up a queue of 5 tutting and impatient customers for nothing! Christchurch, Dorset. Sorry, but I don't feel like you've taken my comments on board. Sainsbury's

column4: I visited Sainsburys at Hankridge Farm Taunton yesterday and usually I am not the kind of person to cause a fuss or complain. But after visiting the restaurant with my two young daughters i was flabbergasted at the sheer lack of organisation and customer service!!! We arrived about 11.45 and with a less than half full restaurant we Queued for over 10 minutes to be served. My children had chosen a sandwich meal deal which you choose the pre made sandwich at the refrigerator. As 1 of my children will only eat a sandwich without butter I decided to pick a pre made sandwich for my youngest child then with intention to ask the staff if they could make a sandwich fresh with no butter. They lady behind the counter was less than helpful and refused point blank to make a sandwich saying   this is something we do not do!!  Feeling annoyed I decided that I would order some hot food instead  but was told that we would have an half an hour wait for hot food. Confused at this point that a restaurant which was not even half full and just before lunchtime was already delayed with hot food by half an hour shows a complete lack of organisation. My biggest complaint is that a restaurant was unable to make a ham sandwich with no butter (2 slices of bread and a piece of ham) is absolutely disgraceful!! We did buy the 1 sandwich meal with the pre made sandwich and neither of my children ate the sandwich as the lumps of butter stuck to the bread made the sandwich inedible. I feel any organisation which provides a food service  particularly children s meals should always have an healthy option and a company of Sainsburys stature should be showing their customers they are fully onboard with the issues regarding obesity concerns with the younger generation. I am Less than a happy customer.
column9: 1st world problems......a restaurant? It's a supermarket cafe, get a grip.

column9: Hi Simon, we're committed to offering great quality products at fair prices which is sourced with integrity.  We regularly review our prices to make sure we offer value for money whilst remaining competitive and we work hard to negotiate great deals with our suppliers.  Although we try to keep our pricing as fair as possible sometimes prices can go up as well as down. Have a nice day, Steve.

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Not sainsburys but the colleague should NOT have made a comment but rather check if mum needed any help

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: This mum is a friend of mine. Joanna Liversidge you are amazing. Xx

column9: Here was my post this afternoon following this..., I AM THAT MUM with THAT CHILD....  So to everyone in the big Sainsbury's this afternoon whilst my youngest was having the meltdown of all meltdowns.....  There are a number of reasons why I as his mum acted like I did :  1) being angry dealing with anger DOES NOT nor will it EVER have a successful outcome for either party  2) hugging and calming (calming and soothing) your child is the best and most effective method of reducing the huge levels of cortisol that are flooding their brains during a meltdown  (if they will let you) â­ï¸just to add here - if a brain floods with cortisol it can 'shut down' the rational, thinking, problem solving part of the brain and so this is NOT a good time to try and reason with them.... physiologically their brain is being high jacked and survival is the focus....they ARE NOT NOT CHOOSING the right choice.... â­ï¸ 3) instilling in your child that they can ask for a hug can be a way of asking for your help because they know they have gone past what they can manage alone 4) I do not condone my son shouting, screaming or hurting me but I am working hard to show him that patience, love, reassurance and sometimes planned ignoring are better and do not leave us both more damaged emotionally or physically 5) modelling has to be just that..... I need to model behaviours that I wish to see in him, even when he appears to have 'lost the plot'. I need to be that role model   And that after giving him the space and love and time for cortisol levels to reduce significantly, we have had a truly beautiful conversation about both our feelings, we both recognise how painful that was for both of us, but that we love each other so wholly unconditionally that nothing will ever come in the way of that. Our behaviour can always be improved but our behaviour is not something that is who we are. We have discussed strategies for dealing with anger but most importantly we have restored peace between us and in his words  ""my heart has screwed itself back together so I can love fully again"".   So to all my mum friends out there, know we ALL have these really challenging and testing times, BUT all we can do is the best we can do!  Love to you all but mostly to my two beautiful children who teach, forgive and love me daily. I love you ALWAYS and am hugely proud to be your mum!!! â¤ï¸ï¸â¤ï¸ï¸â¤ï¸ï¸â¤ï¸ï¸â¤ï¸ï¸  NB Thank you to the one lady who smiled at me whilst I was sat on the floor hugging my son in the middle of an aisle

I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Thank you - your smile was noticed.... and it was the thing that anchored me and kept me on a course that I knew was right for both of us and my eldest daughter who was also with us .... So thank you for not judging, for just acknowledging me and a very tricky situation  The smallest of things meant the hugest of things x x x x x  May we all find the courage to do the same x

column9: Really hope Sainsbury's listen to this comment. As a mum of two (one of which struggles with his emotions) I have had many many a moment very similar to this with customers stood gawping at me and some even passing me by making rude comments about the way I am dealing with my child. This I understand Sainsbury's can not control but to the lovely colleague who once said to me 'my gosh you have a loud child I hear him other end of the store' then walking off was not really helpful. Wish at the time I had complained but unfortunately I was going through a very hard time in my life and my self confidence was at an all time low. Joanna Liversidge you know you are a superstar!! Becky Airey really wish a customer like you has passed by me that day.... a simple smile like that would have made the situation that little bit better..... maybe I wouldn't have then picked my screaming child up and walked out without my shopping as I just needed to leave the place and maybe I would have spent the time in store dealing with my child in the manner I know works for him without feeling the pressure of trying to quieten him down asap. Xx
