The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Do you know I have been ðŸ’­ about the girl on the till quite s lot...... Whilst what she said was upsetting and unnecessary.... can she know what it's like if she's not got children.....?  I know I've made comments in the past and before I knew what on Earth I was talking about..... I'm sure most of us have.....  Let's just hope this is a reminder to us all to be less judgemental and to offer a smile, an are you okay? Or some other supportive gesture when we find others in a similar situation x   Supermarkets...... your stores are full of things to entice people in, full of toys and treats as we approach the festive season.... there will be many many more children coming in, adults with less patience as the ships get busier...... so please please please support your staff to support their customers... nobody knows the complete picture when they see any incident or meltdown.... it's just a snapshot of a much bigger picture ðŸ˜Š

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Still no reply from Sainsburys as yet. I think it was very unnecessary, and it annoys me even more when comments come from people with no children... ðŸ˜’ Because they have absolutely no idea.   I've been contacted anonymously, and now I know the name of the girl on the checkout (confirmed with a photo) so I can make a formal complaint. I spend a lot of money in there, and a comment like that yesterday has made me rethink where I'll be going in future.

column9: Sometimes offering help can be worse if the little ones in over load it can tip them further so kudos to you for being the neutral! Even if you didn't have a child there's nothing wrong with a friendly smile and a thumbs up to the mother or father dealing with a less than ideal moment ^_^ the sad part it no one ever stops and stares when your child exhibits beautiful behaviour because that's 'expected'!! Big sigh of relief when it's done and praise baby for getting through what can only be similar to emotional jenga! Well done mums and dads for winning the daily battles and trying to understand such a complex mind in such a small body xxx

column9: Kids wants everything, I've not known a child who doesn't, and it's a year round thing for us as it's not just Christmas that entices them, it's Halloween, Easter.. Even when there isn't an upcoming event, there's still so much filling their little brains, and it's doing exactly what supermarkets want it to do -  except as an adult we can think rationally about what we buy, and accept it when we can't have something but it's not so easy for children.   Can't believe how many people have reacted and shared my post, thank you so much, it's served its purpose in one way already as I'm glad Joanna got to read it. I'll be very interested to hear what Sainsburys have to say, and any action they take.   Xx

column9: Exactly, you don't know what will be appreciated by the parent. And in that situation, only the parent knows what's best, I just think Joanna dealt with it so well, but the girl on the checkout didn't see that, or what he's like at home when he's not having a meltdown, it's a crappy judgement against a child who can't defend themselves, based on a very small moment in time. Xx

I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: They've replied to posts that were posted after this one, albeit not many. They don't seem to reply very often to visitor posts

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. column9: I have to say I'm really surprised by this,as a mum with 2 kids my eldest girl having Williams syndrome and being on the spectrum this has happened to me at the same store and all the staff that day were incredible (calmed my daughter down and packed my shopping as I was upset) all I would say is its the individual not the store but staff should remember they represent the company while at work.hope it gets sorted x

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Couldn't help but smile at this post . I take my hat of to this woman and the lady who's child was having a melt down . For conducting her self in the manner that she did . Too many people scream and shout at there kids who play up in public spaces , well do e to both of you ladies . Xx

Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Once in Asda when my daughter was having a massive paddy a gentleman thought it was a good idea to tell me how badly behaved she was...I'm not happy with the language I used but he was seconds away from getting his throat ripped out. Like I needed his opinion ðŸ˜¡ðŸ˜¡

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: blonde hair, lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows.""  Lost me at that point - making spiteful comments about a woman's appearance hardly adds to a case where you are pontificating that others should have manners and be less judgemental.  I am sure we have ALL made ill thought comments - no need for the woman to get the sack!

column9: Jacqueline Chivers it must of been a pretty good description because they did find her fast...   If you carried on to the end of this post you'd see that this was not a spiteful person who'd raised this to sainsburys, but more of a mother and a obviously well educated individual, who knows what's right and what's wrong,or do you agree with the sedating comment made?? I think becky put it rather brilliant actually and in a very effective way stating all the facts..   And as a mother to young children I think alot of us all here say well done to Becky Airey and the fact that this was bang out of order...   I think we would all like to see what sainsburys is going to do about this, and if nothing gets written here from sainsburys on the outcome they'll loose alot of custom, like my self who's got young children and wouldn't like to hear that in fact I would be infuriated,   Kind regards.. emma

column9: Bravo. I have often been that mum in the supermarket so I know how it feels when your little ones are not happy and you are very aware of the all the eyes that are on you and all the disapproving looks! It is always nice to see that one smiley face that says I understand what it's like and it reminds you that you are not on your own and that all children go through this. I'm not sure I would've have liked to have heard that comment coming from a member of staff. They have no idea of circumstances and sound like they have no clue on what it can be like having children. Very unprofessional of her.

I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: Are you serious?????

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: How do you know the child didn't have a disability like autism where their behaviour cannot be helped and often afterwards are extremely sorry!  I understand freedom of speech. But freedom of speech would of been "" oh no"" not sedate the child! That's a totally out of order thing to say about a small child who no one knows what's the matter!!

Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: My son has aspergus so yup i certainly do know of such problems to which my son never behaved like that in public places...only when toed to the shed at the back of the garden

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.

A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: is that right? If your actually saying that tying your kid to the shed or lamp post is good discipline then i cant imagine what that child felt like. I don't honestly think this is true and that if it were you would admit this on a public post as this would be seen as child abuse.

column4: I ventured in to your Huddersfield Shorehead store today  as I normally do  a few times a week  it was about 3:30pm. My first port of call was a pair of gloves for my two oldest children. On my way to the clothing I passed a mum with her little boy; he wasn t very happy about something but I didn t bat an eyelid  I m a mum  I know what it s like. A short amount of time passes and I m in the food aisles now  I heard a child crying and shouting  people are literally stopping to stare  and it s this little lad with his mum. I don t know how old he was but I wouldn t say he was older than about 6/7  his mum had to get on the floor to comfort him  and I wanted to go over to her and tell her what an amazing job she was doing considering 1) her little boy was having a massive moment and 2) half the bloody store just stop and stare  some tutting like they ve never seen a child make any noise before. I m still pacing the aisles looking for tinned peaches  which I eventually find and pass the mum again and I just give her a friendly smile  I have been there so many times with my 5 year old who can t deal with super markets  she s got sensory issues with noises  having to sit still  having to be quiet and I ve had the meltdown in the supermarket and the whole world staring many  many times... I eventually get to the checkout and I m bagging up my items when I hear the little boy crying  he s at the checkouts now  a few rows down from me. The girl who is serving me is scanning my items when her colleague behind  who s also scanning someone s shopping  turns around and says very loudly   someone needs to sedate their child.  In absolute shock that she had even said that  I could help but react.  It s not so easy when you ve got kids.  I blurted in her direction  the girls serving me looks a little worried as I think she can also sense that it wasn t the best thing to say.. Maybe it bothered me more because the child was doing exactly what my eldest was doing  and I felt sympathy for her  not annoyance at the child. Even if you thought that the child was  in need of sedating   you wouldn t say it in front of customers. I m pretty sure she didn t have any children  I mean  if she did  she wouldn t have ever come out with a comment like that. I could have been anyone  I could have had my eldest with me  who would have also not been very happy to be there  I could be a mum with a severely autistic child who s struggling with being where they are. It s completely not professional at all and its stayed with me all evening. I wanted to go and give the mum a high five before I left and tell her how well she was still doing  she had patience like no other even by the time she got to the checkout. I know how hard it is to get round the place and keep everything together! I don t know what the girl was called on the checkout  but she was very young  blonde hair  lots of make up with dreadful eyebrows. I m not sure I want to come in the store with my children anymore  so you might have just lost yourself some custom. Today they happened to be waiting in the car with Daddy. Please educate your staff on professionalism and manners!  Share this post  I hope the mum in question sees this  take my hat off to her.
column9: This makes me laff. As a lady with 3 children 1 who had aspergus that sort of behaviour from children is occuring more often unfortunately. Do we not have freedom of speech in our country, its nothing to do with customer service just imagine listening to that 5 tp 6 times a day. Disgraceful behaviour from children in public.

column9: Wow.   5 to 6 times a day? Is that all? I'm surprised you can say it's disgraceful behaviour from children, especially being the mum of 1 who had Aspergers... My eldest repeats herself constantly, once she gets something stuck in her head, it's not disgraceful behaviour, she can't help it!! Its comments like that that will never help children with issues get any acceptance in society. We aren't all perfectly wired up...  Freedom of speech, absolutely! But would the scenario have been different if the boy in question had a visible disability? Would it be acceptable to say such a thing then? I wonder if she would have said what she did to the mothers face? I think not.

column9: Ok, so the eyebrows. As a professional in that field, I'm qualified enough to make that assessment based on what I physically saw. And it was a way to differentiate her against the other girls around on the checkouts. Did I mean it in a hurtful way, no, it's just how I would describe them. I would say that to her face, and I've made comment on many an issues in my time as a very successful beauty therapist/skin consultant/make up artist and teaching of beauty therapy sciences.   Her comment however, was based on nothing more than what she could hear, and quite frankly should have been kept to herself. She's not a mum so has no idea what it's like to have children to deal with. Maybe if she was a parent, she wouldve said something different. She also has no idea what that little boy might be dealing with! She couldn't see him from where she was. Nor did she know the situation(s) leading up to his meltdown. Or if he deals with issues on a daily basis.   When you work with the public, the main objective is not to offend anyone, especially customers who, if it wasn't for them, pay for their wages!

column9: Regarding all stores though, my pet hate are multi buys and other offers that are 'against ' the single person.  Given that there are thousands of us, that's a lot of us to annoy.  In the desert choices there are two of the same flavour in a pack.  I really fancied a spotted dick and a treacle sponge, not two of each.  So on that occasion I was that annoyed that I took one out and replaced it with the other.   Next month perhaps I should start splitting 6 packs of single flavoured yoghurts.  Perhaps put these on You Tube heading 'choices for single peopleðŸ‘ðŸ»' What do you think?

column4: Hi I m sorry to have to get in touch over this but I have never been treated so badly by a shop!! And this is the second time by your staff as well! I was using the restaurant in your Westwood cross store in Thanet Kent. Me and a friend ordered meals and where told it would take 15m due to it being busy which was not a problem  after a while a nice lady brought us the completely wrong meals so they went back  we weighted for a long time then she came back with two meals which we didn t order again  so we weighted again we where talking and didn t notice how long this was all taking we then where completely forgotten about after a hours weight we had enough and decided to go and get our money back  which was fair enough the lady handing out the meals was very apologetic  she went to get the manager who was the opposite  she said to me I had ordered some that wasn t on the menu till lunch and said that was my fault I pointed out that my friend had order a breakfast and we where brought the wrong meals twice also if it wasn t being severed why had you taken my money if I was told I would have ordered something else  no apology she had a really bad attitude!! She took my receipt which is for Â£6.75 and gave me Â£5 back? I asked about the rest and she had taken off for the coffee! I said that most of it was still in the cup on the table as it had gone cold as It was to be with my meal  she just looked blankly at me and refunded my friends money! Still no sorry for making you weight for a hour nothing she just looked really annoyed  I ask here name and said I would take it further as I have never been treated this badly and could not believe the attitude of someone that was supposed to be a manager! her name was Emma On the way out the lady serving me stop apologised bit late but at lest she did! I use your shops all the time and this hole thing makes me want to use Tesco which I don t like but on principle I think I might!
column9: Hi Morgan. Sorry about the experience  you had. Can you PM me the manager's name please? Or pass on a description? Daryl.

column4: Hi  I visited John Lewis at Cheadle yesterday and experienced a parking problem where someone had parked very close next to our car in a non designated spot in a white lined area which not only hampered our ability to get our children in the car but is also dangerous. This is not a new problem and is persistent in those areas and also on double yellow lines along the pavement outside the store. I wrote to JL yesterday but they have advised that they rent spaces from Sainsburys so they are restricted in their ability to manage those spaces. I m therefore writing to you to ask whether you can please put some thought into ensuring these persistent parking issues don t continue. There are plenty of spaces but people appear to be lazy and selfish and don t wish to go and find a space.
column9: Hey Laura. Can you confirm the store for us? You can find them here: http://bit.ly/21oWP3I We don't have the authority to enforce parking regulations. We rely on our customers to be courteous when using the car park. Thanks, Ash.

column9: Ash can you please explain what the point of the hatched areas (and designated parking spaces in general) is if they aren't enforced? It's actually quite dangerous when people park in these areas because you can't see properly to cross the road - especially with small children. Essentially you're saying you take no responsibility and don't care what problems a minority of your customers cause for the rest of us. Tesco have started giving out parking tickets locally to people not abiding by the rules (such as parking in parent and child spaces when they don't have children with them). Perhaps you should look to their example.

column4: Shopping in your Worcester store yesterday for a friend and I picked up the wrong baby milk. Took it back to exchange it for the correct one and was disappointed to be told that I couldn t as I had taken it out of the store. It was in exactly the same condition as when I bought it and I had the receipt  I wasn t even asking for a refund just an exchange  so now I m Â£11 out of pocket and have a tub of milk I can do nothing with  not impressed.
column9: Please explain, this is a product which has a thick plastic lid, and a foil inner for sterilisation purposes. The seal on the plastic hadn't been broken. If I was asking for a refund then I could understand, but not an exchange as I wanted near enough the same product.

column9: Most stores will not refund or exchange baby milk as they would not be able to resell it for safety reasons.  Customers would not wish to purchase a tin that had been returned . As Richard says, stores are not  obliged to refund  or exchange anything  we buy unless it is faulty, most do as a good will gesture, but baby milk has always been one of the exceptions  along with perishable products.  All in terms and conditions online . You could always donate it to an  animal refuge

column4: Am absolutely disgusted with Sainsburys customer service. column9: I refer to part II of the sale of goods act and the Annotation ""For the purposes of this Act, goods are of satisfactory quality if they meet the standard that a reasonable person would regard as satisfactory, taking account of any description of the goods, the price (if relevant) and all the other relevant circumstances."" I consider myself a reasonable person, I would not agree that a TV that lasts 14 months is of satisfactory quality.

column4: Am absolutely disgusted with Sainsburys customer service. column9: when you bought it did it work as it was intended to? yes? then it was fit for purpose. secondly the sales of goods act (1979) is no-longer considered law as it was replaced in October 2015 by the The Consumer Rights Act 2015 which states After the first six months the burden is on you to prove that the product was faulty at the time of delivery.

column9: Whilst we are part of the EU this applies : Under EU rules you always have the right to a minimum 2-year guarantee at no cost.  This 2-year guarantee is your minimum right. National rules in your country may give you extra protection: however, any deviation from EU rules must always be in the consumer's best interest.  If goods you bought anywhere in the EU turn out to be faulty or do not look or work as advertised, the seller must repair or replace them free of charge or give you a price reduction or a full refund.  As a general rule, you will only be able to ask for a partial or full refund when it is not possible to repair or replace the goods.

column4: Can I say a huge THANK YOU to the staff at Nuneaton branch my grandad had a stroke in their car park Friday 28th October if it wasn t for the quick reactions of the car park attendant things could have been alot worse for him. column4: Dear Sainsbury s  I have just bought your own brand UHT soya drink. It tastes good  but I would like to know where do you source your soya (i.e. where your soya grows). It s not written on the package. Many Thanks.
column9: Hey there! Pop over the barcode number and store it's from, I'll find out for you. Chris

column4: Hello Sainsbury s  I d just like to publicly thank the staff at South Woodford s branch who are always lovely but the other day they were exceptionally lovely to my Grandma whose card was declined by the cash machine; it would have been so easy to say  we don t own the machines  or  you need to go to your bank  but your staff called Barclays for her (turns out the card ran out that day and they hadn t posted a new one out - boo hiss!) and stayed with her while she was on the call and looked after her shopping while she popped to her local bank to get money out over the counter. I m afraid I don t know the staff member concerned and of course my Grandma already thanked her but a bit of extra social media gratitude can t hurt!
column9: I'm so sorry I don't know, maybe Wednesday or Thursday, I bet management will know who it was, they're a lovely bunch generally at that store and always as helpful as they are able to be (especially as they have to go get fireworks from the store room for each individual customer each time, it's never too much trouble and they never moan) ðŸ˜ðŸŽ†

column4: I am a great fish lover and eat it most days  I have recently tried to vary the type I purchase and tried the Cape Hake Fillets  although very tasty and flaky I found that being skinless they tend to break up into small fragments whilst being shallow fried  I had thought about using an egg/milk mix to coat them with breadcrumbs but that would defeat my object of trying not to put on weight. column4: I m extremely disappointed with my recent visit to the large Sainsburys in Chippenham  I picked up a jumper marked as half price  there were a few there all marked down and this was a rare treat for myself  it scanned through the till at full price Â£20  so the checkout assistant called over customer service  who then took the jumper to check the system  she then  said she would have to talk to someone from the clothing department to see if it could be sold at Â£10  at this point I just gave up  consumer rights say it should be sold as seen....I was fed up  I felt as though I was being questioned about the pricing of the jumper  if there is a problem on the system that s the company s problem and I should not be made to feel like it s my problem  after 15 minutes of waiting to find out the price of one jumper I walked out  without my rare treat  thanks but no thanks Sainsburys
column9: I'm sorry you left one of our stores disappointed Rebecca. What time & day were you in store? Can you Message us the name of the colleague you dealt with? We'll have this fed back with the relevant team. Debs

column4: Dear Sainsbury s  In your Park Farm West Store in Folkestone  Kent you display a banner proclaiming your proud association with the Royal British Legion for 22 years. I was therefore extremely disappointed and disheartened to see that the poppy man had been relegated to the open foyer area of the store where it was absolutely freezing cold and very windy. Historically the Legion s stand has always been in-store beyond the main doors. I contacted the store and was told that there was no room for the stand in-store as it had to make way for fireworks and a security station. I understand that health and safety is important and that theft is a scourge but I m afraid I cannot believe a better place for the Legion stand could not have been found. The Legion s volunteers are a sturdy and brave bunch and unlikely to complain but I consider they deserve better when helping the rest of us remember those who have made the ultimate sacrifice.
column9: Well said.

column9: Sainsbury's I am (as my original post indicated) well aware of the reasons for locating the Legion stand outside. You have completely missed the point I was making. The Legion's stand should not have had to give way. This is a large superstore. I remained bemused that there was no alternative. The justification for the fireworks point being near the front of the store was health and safety and the ban on customers carrying fireworks around the store. Perhaps next year the firework collection point should be in the car park in a pop up mobile cabin i.e. Order in store at customer services and then retrieve outside thus freeing space up. I do sincerely hope that from Monday the Legion are relocated in-store. Yours a very disappointed customer

column9: Hi, apologies for the confusion. We have investigated this further with the store and the collector chose this spot himself to set up his stall. Amanda.

I contacted the store and was told that there was no room for the stand in-store as it had to make way for fireworks and a security station. I understand that health and safety is important and that theft is a scourge but I m afraid I cannot believe a better place for the Legion stand could not have been found. The Legion s volunteers are a sturdy and brave bunch and unlikely to complain but I consider they deserve better when helping the rest of us remember those who have made the ultimate sacrifice.

I contacted the store and was told that there was no room for the stand in-store as it had to make way for fireworks and a security station. I understand that health and safety is important and that theft is a scourge but I m afraid I cannot believe a better place for the Legion stand could not have been found. The Legion s volunteers are a sturdy and brave bunch and unlikely to complain but I consider they deserve better when helping the rest of us remember those who have made the ultimate sacrifice.

I just called my local branch in Hessle to ask if any pumpkins were still available as I m having a bonfire party tonight and some of mine had gone mouldy. I was wanting them for the kids to be able to carve but I now only had two pumpkins left and 3 kids coming! Unfortunately the store didn t have any pumpkins left however the lady on the phone said she had one herself that wouldn t be used and we was very welcome to have it! Such and lovely woman working in your Hessle Branch who really went above and beyond in her customer service! So thank you very much Lorraine! You have helped me more than you know!!

column4: How pathetic! Les went to Sainsburys for a cooked chicken. 10 already cooked but because their water was off they were not allowed to serve the chicken as the staff wouldn t b able to wash their hands! The staff use a fork to put the chicken in the bag. When he asked what would happen to the 10 chickens he was told they would be thrown away! What!!! Have Sainsburys got bottled water. kettles to boil water to wash hands and gloves to stop hands touching the food. He offered to buy them all for Â£10 but they said they couldn t. Is this Health and safety gone mad or what? What a waste! ðŸ—ðŸ—ðŸ—ðŸ—ðŸ—
column9: Hey there Les, I can assure you that this decision wouldn't have been one we enjoyed making. We're very against food waste and always try our best to keep it to a minimum. In regards to food safety however, we have to play by the rules. Apologies for the frustration! Chris.

column4: Sainsbury s not complying with EU laws? Your granola slices have allergens not clearly labelled on the package. Thanks for making my son ill.
Sainsbury s not complying with EU laws? Your granola slices have allergens not clearly labelled on the package. Thanks for making my son ill.
column9: The label in this product is beyond misleading. It doesn't  say anything about cow's milk, it didn't say that the second most common ingredient is sugar and it didn't say that it contains wheat flour. Stating that we should ask the bakery staff for allergens implies that any possible allergens are due to cross-contamination during the making, and not the 3rd most common ingredient! My son is incredibly sensitive to dairy and he's been ill ever since I started buying this product and I didn't know why. Not to mention that this product is sold as if it was almost healthy, ""oats, fruits and honey"", but it's just a refined sugar and fat bomb.

column9: List of ingredients from your website: Oats (34%), Sugar, Butteroil (Cows' Milk), Sunflower seeds (5%), Cornflour, Cranberry (4%) (Sugar, Cranberry, Sunflower Oil), Sultana (4%), Chilean Flame Raisins (3%), Pumpkin Seeds (3%), Water, Dried Sweetened Sour Cherries (2%) (Cherry, Sugar, Sunflower Oil), Molasses, Raising Agent: Disodium Diphosphate, Sodium Hydrogen Carbonate; Salt, Fortified British Wheat Flour (Wheat Flour, Calcium Carbonate, Iron, Niacin, Thiamin).

column4: Sainsbury s not complying with EU laws? Your granola slices have allergens not clearly labelled on the package. Thanks for making my son ill.
column9: I have bought this product from two different stores and the packaging is always the same. Sainsbury's local in Wokingham  in Ashridge and the superstore in Winnersh. The problem is not with the individual stores but with the discrepancy between what's written in the packaging and what is in the website. Telling customers to ask a member of staff for allergens implies cross contamination only and not misleading labelling.  If you know that there's a lot of milk  and wheat why not say that there is gluten and dairy, preferably in bold. This is standard in all products. Why not say as well that there's a LOT of sugar when in the package you only mention honey. Dodgy and I've lost trust on your products altogether if I have to search online to find out the real ingredients.

column9: I'm sure you have some sort of legal backing for this. So basically what this means is you can write whatever  list of ingredients you'd like on the package and then just tell the customer to take an unnecessary step (just to create confusion) to find out the real list of ingredients. So, you can pretend the product doesn't have sugar (when it's the 2nd most common ingredient), pretend that it has honey (when it doesn't) and pretend that it doesnt have allergens. It's an appalling practice  wich shows that this is not a trustworthy company.

column4: My Blue Hands  I ve had an incident tonight that was both alarming and funny  and I d thought I would share it with you...  I ve been wearing the above jeans all day and I was delighted with my bargain after taking advantage of your recent 25% off offer  however things turned for the worse this evening....   Following a long conversation on my mobile with a friend  I ventured from my sofa to get myself a glass of wine from my kitchen  it was at this point I noticed my hands had turned blue! Luckily a friend was with me  and he looked concerned as he felt them and also said they were cold! Nervously I sat down and started to think something was not quite right. I shook them and rubbed them together but nothing changed the colour.... I did at the same time have a rather nasty pain in my back (which I have had for a couple of days) and I began to think this was linked!! I duly called NHS 111 for their advise. I spoke to an assistant who asked me a 1000 questions about my well being and she assured me I would now be referred to a clinical consultant  who would call back immediately. Anxiously I waited and within minutes I was now speaking with a very helpful medical professional. Again more questions were asked and I was advised to keep my hands above my head and if the colour didn t change it would be best to see my doctor in the morning!!.   My hands were not changing colour... I was worried  I hadn t eaten all day  and I d been in the same position all day doing my tax return  so my friend suggested I go to the fish and chip shop with him  maybe moving would make a difference to the clear lack of circulation... I duly followed his suggestion.  I returned home  could barely touch my fish and chips as I had lost my appetite as my fear grew as the colour hadn t changed at all.   I then called my best friends mum who was an ex nurse maybe she could re assure me! In the meantime my friend went to his van and retrieved a rather old but still functioning blood pressure reading machine. My friends mum asked a number of questions and got me to take my pulse. She then told me a similar incident happened to her daughter (my best friend) where they ended up at A and E  omg I was really getting scared now  and still my hands had not turned back to a normal colour!!!!!!   After assessing my condition once again  My friends mum did add that when she was in A and E they found out that in fact her blue hand condition was in fact the dye from her jeans.......  Yep  you guessed it!!!! I went to the bathroom washed my hands and low and behold the the lather from the soap started turning blue!!!!   Omg  I was so relieved that it was the dye from my new Sainsbury s jeggings and my life wasn t coming to an abrupt end....  I had suffered temporarily from  jegginginitious    Ha ha what a funny evening I ve had  but may I point out to you  that perhaps your dark blue skinny jeans and jeggings need to come with a health warning!!!!  Kind regards  Karren Kent
column9: Hey Karren. This post did make me laugh, I'm glad you're not injured. However, which store did you buy these from? Do you have the item code? Thanks, Ash.

column4: i would just like to tell you that while in my local Penzance store today one of your members of staff was very helpful with myself and my 4 year old son. I went in and between 330 and 345pm my son hit his face on the side of the trolley hard which meant it he cried and bleed  not much but as my son freaks out with blood he went mental crying and causing a scene. One of your members of staff came up to us after a few seconds asking my son if he was ok and if he would like a drink. He was very helpful and grabbed my son a bottle of drink free of charge to help him out and calm him down. This was very helpful and restored my faith in humanity. All i know is that he was called Mark and he was with a few other workers making the shelves look tidy. i would love for him to get recognized for this. It doesn t seem much or a big deal but this helped my son out as he felt so much better and so we could carry on shopping without anymore fuss and looks so thank you Mark.

I went in and between 330 and 345pm my son hit his face on the side of the trolley hard which meant it he cried and bleed  not much but as my son freaks out with blood he went mental crying and causing a scene. One of your members of staff came up to us after a few seconds asking my son if he was ok and if he would like a drink. He was very helpful and grabbed my son a bottle of drink free of charge to help him out and calm him down. This was very helpful and restored my faith in humanity. All i know is that he was called Mark and he was with a few other workers making the shelves look tidy. i would love for him to get recognized for this. It doesn t seem much or a big deal but this helped my son out as he felt so much better and so we could carry on shopping without anymore fuss and looks so thank you Mark.
column9: Ricky Lattimer thank you

column4: How do you get around not having to provide nutritional content?! Bought a pack of Taste the Difference salted caramel and Belgian milk chocolate cookies this morning and there is no nutritional content for them in the packet - not even an ingredients list or any allergen information! It says to speak to a member of the bakery team - which is hard when they are from a mini convince store where there is no bakery department.  Thought I would check out your website  and li and behold while you list the ingredients  there is still no nutritional information!
column9: Too late! After suffering an allergic reaction, my friend has called Sainsbury's to be told that Palm Oil is an ingredient and she should avoid all TtD range!!! Unfortunately TravelEx have different opening times advertised to what is on there answer machine & what is given when you ring the helpline number meaning I missed collecting my travel money before going on holiday! column4: Big Thank you to First Aiders and Petrol Filling Station staff at York Monks Cross  I rather stupidly managed to slash my head open with my car boot (new car) on Tuesday 1st November at around noon in York Monk s Cross filling station.   I want to say a massive thank you to the petrol filling station staff and first aider s who took care of me that day until the paramedics turned up. I do not know the first aiders names but the cashier Lauren was brilliant too!  Not only were they brilliant with me  but also went out of their way to help my friend who was with me to keep my 3 year old occupied with magazines and chocolate so she didn t become distressed at the sight of me covered in blood and passing out! I commend Sainsbury s for all their assistance that day.  I didn t get chance to say thank you on the day as  was taken to a&e by ambulance with concussion and had my head glued. But a big thank you. You made a horrible experience just that little bit better!
column9: Hope your ok Sarah India Jade Allan,  and well done Sainsbury's xx

column4: Sainsbury s Energy I can t believe you have got my energy bill wrong AGAIN even though you agreed the tariff a week ago. Appalling customer service. So unhappy! I am starting to think you are making up the energy charges on my account and just take what you like each month :-(
column9: Ha ha, that is a joke. I have had a complaint open with them for over a month now and they still cannot sort themselves or the issue out.  Despite agreeing to move to a cheaper tariff, hoping to correct any issues, it seems to have complicated things further as they are now charging me more for it as well as the unresolved issues that were raised last month.  No more faith in them. False information, extra charges without explanation, agreements not kept, failure to respond when previously arranged, case left to sit for over a week by personal account manager despite promise to sort before this date, and ran over next payment date causing further issues financially. Now considering alternative providers. Totally fed up and stressed out.  NO THANKYOU Sainsbury's Energy.

column4: I received a delivery on Monday evening which should have included a bottle of wine. After piling the boxes on my doorstep the driver mumbled that he d smashed the bottle of wine and had refunded the amount. I felt sorry for him as thought he d had a bad day. Felt less sorry as I was unpacking my shopping and having to wipe everything down as the wine had obviously spilt over everything. However  no refund has appeared so tonight I have spent over an hour on the phone to your customer services who have tried in vain to contact the Bodmin store. I also tried myself only to have the line cut off each time they answered. Eventually  after an hour on the phone to customer services they said they would refund the bottle of wine themselves. And guess what ... that meant being transferred to the refund department which meant yet another wait of 15 minutes on hold. Absolutely appalling service and I ve wasted an hour trying to sort it. I should have just written the money off but I guess that s what Sainsbury s hope for otherwise why make the refund system so flipping convoluted. At the end of the conversation I asked to register a complaint. No surprise  I was put on hold again. Gave up after 6 minutes. Shocking.
column9: Hi Sam,  yes, will do so now.

column4: I don t rant very often on here but was actually quite disappointed to see my local Sainsbury s giving pumpkins away for free after Halloween. Why if the pumpkins are still good enough to advertise and give away for free are they not being given to homeless shelters or organisations so they can make dishes for those of us unfortunate enough not to have warm homes at this time of year.
column9: Carving pumpkins sold at this time of year are not really edible. They are grown specifically for robustness and size and more chemicals are used to preserve them. You could cook them, but they're likely to be very bland and fibrous.

column4: Dear Sainsbury I ve made a complaint over the phone on 26 September about your store in Odd Down  Bath. I am still to receive a call back from you  that you promised me. I went back to the store on 23 October and requested to speak to store manager  Lindsay Cole. Once again  she wasn t available  I was told by Duty Manager - Gary. He s promised to get the store manager to call me  investigate the original complaint and why customer services didn t call em back. As you can guess  no one has called me back. On top of that  while I was in store speaking to Gary  two members of staff stood behind him and listen to the whole conversation. After I ve walked away  my partner was still stood there and heard the lady called Cay say about me :  people would just do anything to get something for free  !!! I ve just called your customer service people again and it was most frustrating and infuriating experience of my life. No one could tell me why I haven t received a call back or offer any other resolution apart from contacting the store manager and asking them again to call me back. I am not prepared to wait another month to hear a reason why no one called me back in first place. I am not interested in the reason why  it is simply unacceptable  there is no valid reason for this to ever happen. I asked to be put through to a manager  a person called James who introduced himself as an Online  Manager had told me that he needs to find out why the store didn t get in touch with me and there is nothing else he can do for me. When I told him this isn t good enough and I am not prepared to deal directly with the store after I ve been treated by staff in such awful manner. James became really nervous on the phone  admitted that he doesn t usually speak to customers on the phone and when I suggested he should put me through to someone who knows how to deal with customers over the phone - he hung up! I am livid and just beyond disappointed with the level of customer service you provide. You ve wasted a lot of my time  cause me stress and upset. I would like to know: is this Sainsbury s stand on how to treat customers? Do you not tell your employees not to make derogatory comments about customers in store  especially while those customers are still ins tore shopping? Is it normal to hung up on customers who is upset because they ve been waiting for a call back for over a month and been insulted in the store? I m appalled. Speechless. I ve spent thousands of pounds in your store this year alone. I am not planning to set my foot in any of your stores ever again.
column9: Hi Magda, sorry about this. So that we can help, can you PM me with the details of your complaint? We'll address this today for you. Ryan.

column4: Hi Sainsbury s! I saw a campaign from you yesterday around the Fenchurch area (not sure if it was the Fenchurch St branch) whereby your team was handing out free sandwiches  as well as a voucher for the On the Go range. This was a lovely treat and I m sure everyone enjoyed their free lunch. It did strike me  however  that these free lunches were given to people generally who could buy their own  with no real explanation of the campaign  rather than the number of homeless people in the area who I m sure would have appreciated it a whole lot more. I chose to give my sandwich away to someone who really needed it  and I wondered if you would consider this in the future. Jemma
column9: Hi Jemma, thanks for getting in touch! Each of our stores have their own arrangements for supporting local charities, food banks and the like, which is all arranged at store level. While I understand where you're coming from, this will have been to promote the new On the Go range and help encourage new lunch time shoppers who would normally go elsewhere. If you're interested in discussing something like this, pop in and speak to your nearest superstore's PR Ambassador - they'd love to chat to you about this. Ryan.

column4: Quick question: does anyone do their weekly online food shop to be consumed in a day or two?   Well sainsburys think it s completely acceptable that you do.  Yet again after giving them the benefit of the doubt  they send me fresh produce in a 3pm delivery slot to be used by that day.  Their stance is its to reduce their food waste but it would seem they have no problem increasing ours  the consumer.  So basically we save them money as they offload their soon to be (questionable that it s not already) out of date stuff and basically we re out of pocket as we have to bin it.  Hmm that seems fair...  If you re a binge eater great then this is the shop for you. If like I  you do a weekly shop to last you the week then I suggest you save your money and get to a shop yourself.

column4: Well Sainsbury  you really acquitted yourselves extremely badly this time! I usually don t have any problems with my online shopping but this time you just mucked up ROYALLY! Firstly  my shopping  due between 8 and 9pm  arrived sometime around 8:40pm  the driver said he d tried to call me on my mobile phone  I had no missed call  nor did I have any voice-mail message. Before the driver arrived I d been on the phone to customer services  who tried to contact the store from where my shopping was being delivered  they couldn t get any decent answer  and I was informed that  if my shopping didn t arrive that night  a customer services rep would call the store and call me. When my shopping arrived  there were missing items  2 x plain bagels  2 x cinnamon and raisin bagels and a bag of sugared ring doughnuts...the ONLY things I actually wanted  everything else could have been ordered from Ocado (which I subsequently did because I sent my order back!) I thought I might have heard from Sainsbury today  with a full explanation  but I have not heard a peep from you  I m absolutely disgusted!!

column4: These days I think we don t give enough credit where its due...I have to share todays experience because it meant so much to me........ I was shopping in Sainsburys on my own with both girls...Daisy was riding inside the trolley and Poppy was in the seat...During our shop (lots in the trolley) Poppy started to get grizzley...so I carried her for a while and she fell asleep on my shoulder! I got to the till and the Cashier  Pam ...saw me and instantly offered assistance to unload the trolley...being a bit stubborn and proud I declined...the lady customer in front of me then offered to help and started unloading my trolley....Pam then summoned a colleague over and insisted I let her help...along with Daisy this kind lady unloaded my whole trolley...chatting to Daisy throughout. Pam then packed all my shopping into bags and loaded them back into my trolley. Those three ladies might just see what they did as part of their job or duty but it really did mean so much to me...and totally made my day.Thank you Pam/her colleague and lady customer of sainsbury s Lordshill!!!!! Xx
column9: That's amazing feedback Tracey, I've forwarded this to management in store so the colleagues can be recognised.Thanks for taking the time to share it with us, it made my morning. Have a good day. Faiza.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Fair point...but aren't we all encouraged to wash fruit and veg before we eat it?

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Yet, children, under the supervision of adults, are encouraged to carve pumpkins, with sharp knives...surely that is the easiest way for nasties to get into the blood?

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: If it's watered with waste water, I think it's more to do with the the pumpkins being full of gunk than covered it it. I was looking at brewing a pumpkin beer/mead and would have had to buy edible pumpkins which are way more expensive (even though they'd be washed and boiled).  Not sure about carving pumpkins with knives though. The kits for kids aren't sharp and I used a dremel.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Surely boiled anything has the nasties removed (after all, you boil water to remove bugs?).....then it turns to alcohol?

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Boiling takes away all (or at least most) of the bacteria before it goes into the fermenting vessel, so it must be a poison risk rather than bacterial risk.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Poison....really? And this is not mentioned on the Pumpkin merchandise?

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: As I said earlier, I could be wrong. Just going by advice for an experienced brewer who has 30+ years of experience over me. The only other real reasons there would be for the edible/carving pumpkin divide are quality and taste (edible pumpkins are very fleshy where as carving ones are hollow and/or stringy).  If the risk is even small, it could be a minefield for Sainsbo's. I'm as much for supermarket donating food waste to charity as anyone else but don't think trying to publicly shame a business over something like this is the way to gain support.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: I believe it's to do with carving pumpkins (which is pretty much all UK pumpkins unless advertised as edible), having no quality control (or very little). They can be watered using waste water from the farm and full of nasties.  I could be wrong though.
