column9: I'm interested, only because Lidl were offering pumpkins, for 19p...a reduction of 80% but at no point was it made clear that they were not for human consumption....I'm sure knorr would have something to say about this!!

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Julia Sironi we have registered with Sainsburys in Sixfields to collect their waste since April but it's been very hit and miss.   It's taken a while for Kate (our volunteer) to build up a rapport with the store but the determined and wonderful person she is, she has managed to get on terms with the bakery department to donate regularly.   The problem is with groceries and fresh produce. According to the store, they have to be signed off before they can be donated but as we can't always wait, Kate has been morning, afternoon and even night time to pick up to no avail. Then if we don't pick up it all goes to waste. It's their store policy not to donate food that has gone past both use and best before dates, which is crazy but we have to respect, for the time being.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: It's not policy Simon Poon it's the law that food cannot be given away after the use by or best before date

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: no it is not.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: It's not Law, we get donated food by Morrisons, Ocado, Waitrose and many more retailers. The only law is to sell food that is gone past its use by date, it's not law to sell food past its best before date. Supermarkets brain wash the public into believing that dates are the be and end of it all, it's not. Butchers don't have dates in their stores when selling you a cut of meat. What happened to common sense?

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Only going off the training I've been given

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: As far as I was aware Use by: was to protect the vendor. BBE: was to protect the consumer

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: I appreciate that Steven and not having a go at you. Just need to realise the ridiculous amount of food we waste in this country, the UK is the biggest waster of food in Western Europe. In the UK last year over 1 million people turned to food banks yet we waste millions of tonne of food. It's like bread, think of the time and effort to grow flour, the energy it costs to cook it, the packaging and if it doesn't get sold it goes to waste. We rescue easily close to half a tonne of food destined for landfill every week from a small selection of retailers and it's shocking to see what gets wasted. We're only a small section in Northampton, nationally it must be scandalous!

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: We have a strict policy to follow and unfortunately it's not as easy as giving food away. As harsh as it it we do have to stick to policy

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Surely it is not good for children to be carving pumpkins that are hazardous/

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Many thanks.

column4: Now hear this:  Apparently  being overstocked with pumpkins this year and trying to sell them off cheap....well  who d have known this one........They will NOT donate their overstock to Real Junk Food Project or food banks.....Why? Apparently they are not edible!!! Now  please explain?
column9: Hey Julia! Carving pumpkins are edible, but it's not recommended to eat them. We operate a zero waste to landfill policy and while we've reduced the price of the pumpkins, any we have left over will be put to good use. As with all our items, if we can't sell them we'll either donate them to local foodbanks (where suitable), turn them into animal feed to support British farmers or send them for anaerobic digestion to turn into green energy that powers one of our stores. Each store makes arrangements with local charities at store level, so I'd recommend getting in touch with them for more info! More info on this here: http://bit.ly/1A2wsE0 - Ryan.

( the issue retails to a purchase of fuel we made during the Sainsbury s/Nectar Swipe to Win weekend...we purchased a qualifying sum of fuel but due to an error made by the cashier when paying my Nectar card didn t scan correctly so I didn t receive my bonus points coupon. ) I was then sent into the customer services desk in store where I was advised that my claim would need to be dealt with manually and in due course I would be contacted with regards to the addition of the specific bonus points I d won for that specific transaction. I received all my other bonus points coupons instantly over the Swipe to Win weekend without any further issues but obviously I wish to pursue my missing bonus points award on the fuel purchase. Sainsbury s told me it would be dealt with by Nectar yet Nectar advised me it would be Sainsbury s?!?  Can you help by clarifying the situation please as I m a little confused by it all ðŸ¤” Thank you
column9: Hi there. The 500 points were added by Debs as you were unable to take advantage of the Swipe and Win offer. I can see Debs had explained the points were an apology for missing out on the promotion. Sorry for the confusion. Naomi.

column9: Dear Karren Thanks for getting in touch about the shelf life of our JS ISB Cherry Scones x 4 and JS ISB Plain Scones x 4. I'm sorry that when you bought the aforementioned items from our Hinckley store they had exceeded both their display by and best before dates.This incident certainly isn't up to our usual high standards and we have strict stock rotation and checking procedures in place that should prevent it from happening. I've been in touch with my colleagues in our Hinckley store and they will investigate this issue and ensure that staff are more vigilant in the future. As a result of this happening I'd like to apply Â£10.00 worth of Nectar points to your card ending 5018. Please allow between 3 - 5 working days for them to be applied. I've also logged your comments so that my colleagues both in store and in our trading teams are aware of them. They regularly review our customers' comments to make sure they're meeting our high quality standards, and I'm confident that they'll monitor this issue closely moving forward. We appreciate you contacting us about this and hope to see you shop with us again soon. Kind regards Ian Morgan | Sainsbury's Careline Hope this helps, Megan.

column4: Absolutely SHOCKING service from Sainsbury s today. An order that was supposed to be delivered yesterday was advised last minute as not coming  rearranged to this morning whereby the driver gave our shopping to a completely different address - had to retrieve it but only I called asking where he was - finally arriving at my house with a load of unadvised (and random) substitutions  missing items  no commentary from the driver who was then blocking the road (so practically dropped the bags and then bolted off again)  45mins on the phone to Customer Service to receive nothing more than a refund for those items we could immediately identify as missing but charged. Definitely less that ideal!

column4: Dear Sainsbury s.  Am standing in your St Marks Wolverhampton store where I ve come to collect my eBay parcel on click and collect service. Am somewhat disturbed to find that no one knows how to do it. Someone called Sam has cleared off with the instruction book and no one has been trained in how to locate and hand over my order.  Absolutely abysmal customer service and care. I suggest Sainsbury s look into their staff training and not offer services that no one knows how to carry out. I desperately need my parcel tonight which is why I opted for the click and collect service and have been here over twenty minutes so far with no clue when this mystical Sam will appear with instructions or even if Sam has gone home.  I need my parcel Sainsbury s.  Am becoming rather annoyed.
column9: Hi Beckii, did you receive your order in the end? I've fed your comments back to the manager who will look into this. Thanks for getting in touch. Have a nice day. Daryl.

column4: Dear Sainsbury s.  Am standing in your St Marks Wolverhampton store where I ve come to collect my eBay parcel on click and collect service. Am somewhat disturbed to find that no one knows how to do it. Someone called Sam has cleared off with the instruction book and no one has been trained in how to locate and hand over my order.  Absolutely abysmal customer service and care. I suggest Sainsbury s look into their staff training and not offer services that no one knows how to carry out. I desperately need my parcel tonight which is why I opted for the click and collect service and have been here over twenty minutes so far with no clue when this mystical Sam will appear with instructions or even if Sam has gone home.  I need my parcel Sainsbury s.  Am becoming rather annoyed.
column9: Eventually!  after much ado and  panic from the ladies on the customer service kiosk. And possibly due to the fact I said I would remain at the kiosk until someone found my item even if I had to grab a blanket and cushions from the shelves and spend the evening in the TV department watching repeated adverts. The young lady I saw told me that they hadn't been trained in how to deal with click and collect for eBay at all. One lady knew how to deal with a DPD collection so that dealt with the elderly gent behind me in the queue. Mystical Sam who never appeared had apparently gone and taken the instruction sheet with her according to the harassed young girl dealing with me. Eventually a more mature lady materialised and took control of things somewhat - informing me that she was Sam's best mate! Hallelujah! Sam does exist after all! This lady valiantly tried to defend Mystical Sam and informed me that Sam had told her on the telephone that she had shown everyone how to deal with eBay collections etc. I wasn't buying it! Doesn't seem she did it very well judging by the fact the young lady ""Lauren"" I think her name was bless her, and several other colleagues stood looking traumatised and mystified and Lauren looked about to burst into tears or spontaneously combust. In fact,  she looked more annoyed than I did. Which I felt rather indignant about to be fair ... I was the one being inconvenienced after all.  However. After half an hour of faffing about my parcel appeared only for another performance  of no one knowing which code to enter into the dreaded handheld device in order that they mark it delivered.  Pretty appalling stuff really after a long day at work where I'd opted for what I assumed would be the quicker and more convenient option from such a large and reputable company.

column4: Are your  Monster  pumpkins edible?  I picked up a couple today and then someone told me they were for carving not eating?! Are they food-safe? Thank you!
column9: Thank you! ðŸ˜€ðŸŽƒ

column4: Are your  Monster  pumpkins edible?  I picked up a couple today and then someone told me they were for carving not eating?! Are they food-safe? Thank you!
column9: Hi Emma, the carving pumpkins are edible although we recommend not to eat them. The varieties grown for carvers and monsters are designed to grow large and be robust so that they can be carved. They are not the best tasting varieties. If customers would like to eat pumpkin we recommend our Edible pumpkin product. These are specially selected varieties which have higher levels of sugar and taste great. Steven

column4: Are your  Monster  pumpkins edible?  I picked up a couple today and then someone told me they were for carving not eating?! Are they food-safe? Thank you!
column9: So basically Emma Eames sainsburys want you to spend more money instead of using a perfectly edible product. Just try it and its either going to be nice or not so much

column4: Are your  Monster  pumpkins edible?  I picked up a couple today and then someone told me they were for carving not eating?! Are they food-safe? Thank you!
column9: Jack David Warner Well, that didnt work seeing as the reason I was asking is that my local Sainsbury's was giving away the carving ones for free yesterday!!! :)

column4: Are your  Monster  pumpkins edible?  I picked up a couple today and then someone told me they were for carving not eating?! Are they food-safe? Thank you!
column9: Emma Eames  actually to be fair...it DOES work. Sainsbury's are advocating you DONT eat the carving pumpkins ( when you clearly can, albeit they wont have quite the flavour of those grown for eating)instead they want you to buy their more expensive eating versions ( which retailer wouldn't?)  FWIW carving pumpkins with the addition of a little cumin, coriander, cream and time, make a lovely soup....and to be equally fair to Sainsbury's, the eating versions are a lot more versatile and have more standalone flavour.

column4: Are your  Monster  pumpkins edible?  I picked up a couple today and then someone told me they were for carving not eating?! Are they food-safe? Thank you!
column9: You can eat them, the difference between carving and eating pumpkins is the carving ones have a thinner skin and less meat...ideal for carving. The flesh tends to be more watery and stringy than those grown for eating. HTH

I said nevermind and continued with my other shopping.

column9: I've passed your comments onto the store management and the cafe manager would like to give you a phone to discuss this. Would you be able to give me a number we can reach you on? Thanks, Steve.

column4: Absolutely disgusting the breakfasts me and my mate got served with at your Heaton store in Newcastle upon Tyne. Very appalling service at the very least.
column9: It's easier saying what was right.....we waiting ages to be served by a lass who was on her own which wasn't the problem as such. What was the problem is we ordered 2 breakfasts at a cost of Â£4.55 each. When both breakfasts arrived we got a plate each with a mushroom, bacon and scrambled egg on it. When I asked where the beans and hash browns were she brought them out on separate plates with 1 sausage each. When we asked where the other sausage was she apologised and came out with ANOTHER plate with 2 sausages on it. The toast we got was seeded bread, not the toast we wanted and both came with mushrooms that wasn't even on the board. We were made to look like pigs with 3 plates each. Worse Sainsbury's cafe I've ever been to.

column4: Sainsbury s  I get that you need to use substitutions sometimes for online shoppers  this is understandable; but for the second time today I received a DIFFERENT SIZE nappy rather than a different brand. How does this make sense? The nappies I received obviously don t fit my baby and now I have to go out shopping to get these essentials  defeating the object of online shopping. Surely this could be done better?
column9: Hi Gemma, I'm so sorry for the inconvenience. Did the drover make you aware of the substitution? Could you PM over your order number and the name of the account holder please? Cheryl

column4: Sainsbury s. Identify that the sandwich offering is poor. Release a new range of better sandwiches to address the problem. Limit the meal deal to those tired old sandwiches they identified as tragic. Perpetuate lunchtime sales to tesco  boots and M&S. Good job Sainsbury s marketing & product development teams!
column9: Sorry Megan, think the jist was missed.... I was saying the drive to improve the lunch trade kinda backfired by introducing decent sandwiches then excluding all but the worst from the lunch deal...
